1.1: The book of the genealogy of Yeshua The Messiah, The Son of David, The Son of Abraham.
1.2: Abraham begot Isaaq, Isaaq begot Jaqob, Jaqob begot Yehuda and his brothers.
1.3: Yehuda begot Pharez and Zarah from Tamar. Pharez begot Hezron, Hezron begot Aram.
1.4: Aram begot Aminadab, Aminadab begot Nahshon, Nahshon begot Salmon
1.5: Salmon begot Boaz from Rahab, Boaz begot Obayd from Ruth, Obayd begot Jesse.
1.6: Jesse begot David the King, David begot Solomon from the wife of Uriah.
1.7: Solomon begot Rehoboam, Rehoboam begot Abia, Abia begot Asa.
1.8: Asa begot Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat begot Joram, Joram begot Uzaya.
1.9: Uzaya begot Jotham, Jotham begot Ahaz, Ahaz begot Hezekiah.
1.10: Hezekiah begot Manashe, Manashe begot Amon, Amon begot Joshaiah.
1.11: Joshaiah begot Jokania and his brothers in the captivity of Babel.
1.12: After the captivity of Babel, Jokania begot Shelathiel, Shelathiel begot Zorubabel.
1.13: Zorubabel begot Abiud, Abiud begot Eliakim, Eliakim begot Azor.
1.14: Azor begot Zadoq, Zadoq begot Akin, Akin begot Eliud.
1.15: Eliud begot Eliazer, Eliazer begot Matthan, Matthan begot Yaqob.
1.16: Yaqob begot Yoseph the guardian of Maryam, her from whom was begotten Yeshua, who is called The Messiah.
1.17: Therefore all generations from Abraham until David were fourteen generations, and from David until the captivity of Babel, fourteen generations, and from the captivity of Babel until The Messiah, fourteen generations.
1.18: The birth of Yeshua The Messiah was thus: when Maryam his mother was engaged to Yoseph before they would have a conjugal relation she was found pregnant from The Spirit of Holiness.
1.19: But Yoseph her lord was righteous and did not want to expose her, and he was considering divorcing her secretly.
1.20: But as he considered these things, The Angel of THE LORD JEHOVAH appeared to him in a dream and said unto him, “Yoseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Maryam your woman, for he who is begotten in her is from The Spirit of Holiness.”
1.21: “And she shall bring forth a Son, and she shall call his name Yeshua, for he shall save his people from their sins.”
1.22: Now all this happened, that the thing which was spoken from THE LORD JEHOVAH by the Prophet would be fulfilled:
1.23: “Behold the virgin shall conceive, and she shall bear a son, and they shall call his Name Emmanuail, which is translated, 'Our God is with us'“.
1.24: And when Yoseph arose from his sleep, he did according to that which The Angel of THE LORD JEHOVAH had commanded him, and he took his wife.
1.25: And he did not know her sexually until she delivered her firstborn son, and she called his name Yeshua.

2.1: Now when Yeshua was born in Bethlehem of Judaea, in the days of Herodus the King, The Magi came from The East to Jerusalem.
2.2: And they were saying, “Where is The King of the Judaeans who has been born?” For we have seen his star in The East and we have come to worship him.
2.3: But Herodus The King heard and he was troubled and all Jerusalem with him.
2.4: And he gathered the Chief Priests and the Scribes of the people together and was asking them, “Where would The Messiah be born?”
2.5: And they said, “In Bethlehem of Judaea”, for thus it is written in The Prophets:
2.6: “You, Bethlehem of Judea, were not the least among the Kings of Judaea, for from you shall proceed The King who shall shepherd my people Israel.”
2.7: And then Herodus secretly called The Magi and learned from them at what time the star had appeared to them.
2.8: And he sent them to Bethlehem and said to them, “Go inquire about The Boy very carefully and when you find him, come show me, so that I also may go worship him.”
2.9: But when they heard from the King, they went, and behold, that star which they had seen in The East went before them, until it came and stood over where The Boy was.
2.10: And when they saw the star, they rejoiced with a very great joy.
2.11: And they entered the house and saw The Boy with Maryam his mother, and they fell and worshiped him and opened their treasures and offered him gifts: gold, myrrh, and frankincense.
2.12: And it was seen by them in a dream that they should not return to Herodus, and they went to their country by another road.
2.13: And as they went, The Angel of THE LORD JEHOVAH appeared in a dream to Yoseph, and said to him, “Arise, take The Boy and his mother, and flee to Egypt and stay there, until I speak to you, for Herodus is going to seek The Boy to destroy him.”
2.14: So Yoseph arose, took The Boy and his mother in the night, and fled to Egypt.
2.15: And he was there until the death of Herodus, that the thing might be fulfilled that was spoken from THE LORD JEHOVAH through the Prophet which says, “From Egypt I have called my Son.”
2.16: And Herodus, when he saw that he was mocked by The Magi, was greatly enraged, and he sent and killed all the boys of Bethlehem and of all of its borders, from two years old and under, according to the time he had searched out from the Magi.
2.17: Then the thing was fulfilled which was spoken by Jeremiah the Prophet which says:
2.18: “In Ramtha a voice was heard: weeping and great lamentation, Rachel weeping over her children, and she is unwilling to be comforted, because they are not.”
2.19: But when Herodus The King died, The Angel of THE LORD JEHOVAH appeared in a dream to Yoseph in Egypt.
2.20: And he said to him, “Arise, take The Boy and his mother, and go to the land of Israel, for those who were seeking the Boy's life have died.”
2.21: And Yoseph arose, took The Boy and his mother, and came to the land of Israel.
2.22: But when he heard that Arkilaus was The King in Judaea, in the place of Herodus his father, he was afraid to go there, and it appeared to him in a dream that he should go to the region of Galilee.
2.23: And he came to dwell in a city that is called Nazareth, so that the thing would be fulfilled which was spoken by the Prophet, “He shall be called The Nazarene.”

3.1: And in those days Yohannan The Baptizer came and was preaching in the desert of Judaea.
3.2: And he said, “Return to God, the Kingdom of Heaven has come near.”
3.3: For this was he of whom it was said by Isaiah the Prophet, “A voice that cries in the desert, 'Prepare the way of THE LORD JEHOVAH and level his paths'.”
3.4: And this Yohannan had his garment of camel hair and wore a leather garment around his waist, and his food was locusts and honey of the field.
3.5: Then Jerusalem and all Judaea were going out to him, and the whole region, which is around the Jordan.
3.6: And they were being baptized by him in the Jordan River while confessing their sins.
3.7: But when he saw many of the Pharisees and the Sadducees who came to be baptized, he said to them, “Offspring of vipers, who has instructed you to flee from the wrath that is coming?”
3.8: “Produce therefore fruit that is fitting of repentance.”
3.9: “And do not think and say in yourselves, 'Abraham is our father', for I say to you, God can raise up from these stones children to Abraham.”
3.10: “But behold, the axe is laid at the root of the tree; every tree, therefore, that has not produced good fruit is cut down and falls into the fire.”
3.11: “I am baptizing you in water for repentance, but he who comes after me is mightier than I, for I am not worthy to pick up his sandals; he is to baptize you in The Spirit of Holiness and in fire.”
3.12: “For the winnowing fan is in his hand and he purges his threshing floor, and he gathers the wheat into his barns, and the chaff he will burn in fire that is not extinguished.”
3.13: Then Yeshua came from Galilee to the Jordan unto Yohannan to be baptized by him.
3.14: But Yohannan had refused and said to him, “I need to be baptized by you, and you have come to me?”
3.15: But Yeshua answered and said to him, “Allow this now, for it is proper for us to fulfill all justice”, and then he allowed him.
3.16: But when Yeshua was baptized, at once he came up from the water, and Heaven was opened unto him, and he saw The Spirit of God descending like a dove and coming upon him.
3.17: And behold a voice from Heaven that said, “This is my Son, The Beloved, in whom I am delighted.”

4.1: Then Yeshua was led of The Spirit of Holiness to the wilderness to be tempted by The Devil.
4.2: But he fasted forty days and forty nights, and afterward he was hungry.
4.3: And The Tempter approached him and said to him, “If you are The Son of God, tell these stones to become bread.”
4.4: But he answered and said, “It is written: 'A man does not live by bread only, but by every word that proceeds from the mouth of God.' “
4.5: Then The Devil brought him to The Holy City, and stood him on the pinnacle of The Temple.
4.6: And he said to him, “If you are The Son of God, cast yourself down, for it is written: 'He will command his Angels concerning you, and they will carry you upon their hands, lest you strike your foot on a stone'.”
4.7: Yeshua said to him, “Again it is written: 'You shall not tempt THE LORD JEHOVAH your God.' “
4.8: Again The Devil brought him to a very high mountain, and he showed him all the Kingdoms of the world and their glory.
4.9: And he said to him, “All these things I will give to you if you will fall down to worship me.”
4.10: Then Yeshua said to him, “Depart Satan, for it is written: 'You shall worship THE LORD JEHOVAH your God and him alone shall you serve.' “
4.11: And The Devil left him, and behold Angels approached and they were serving him.
4.12: But when Yeshua heard that Yohannan had been delivered up, he departed to Galilee.
4.13: And he left Nazareth, and came to dwell in Kapernahum, by the side of the sea, in the borders of Zebulon and of Naphtali.
4.14: That the thing which was spoken by Isaiah the Prophet would be fulfilled which says:
4.15: “The land of Zebulon, the land of Naphtali, the way of the sea, the crossings of Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles.”
4.16: “The people who sat in the darkness have seen The Great Light, and those who were sitting in the region and in the shadow of death, to them The Light has dawned.”
4.17: From then on, Yeshua began to preach and to say, “Return to God, for The Kingdom of Heaven has come near.”
4.18: And as he was walking on the side of the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers, Shimeon who was called Kaypha, and Andraeus his brother, for they were casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
4.19: And Yeshua said to them, “Come after me, and I shall make you to become fishers of men.”
4.20: And at once they left their net and they went after him.
4.21: And when he passed from there, he saw two other brothers: Yaqob Bar Zebedee and Yohannan his brother, in a boat with Zebedee their father, who were setting their nets in order, and he called them.
4.22: And at once they left the boat and their father and they went after him.
4.23: And Yeshua was traveling about in all Galilee and he taught in their assemblies and was preaching The Gospel of the Kingdom and curing every sickness and disease among the people.
4.24: And his fame was heard in all Syria, and they brought to him all those who had become ill with various diseases, those who were afflicted with severe pain, and the demon possessed, and lunatics and paralytics, and he healed them.
4.25: And great crowds went after him from Galilee and from the Ten Cities and from Jerusalem and from Judaea and from the other side of the Jordan.

5.1: But when Yeshua saw the crowds, he went up into a mountain and when he sat down his disciples came near to him.
5.2: And he opened his mouth and he was teaching them and he said:
5.3: “Blessed by The Spirit are the poor, because theirs is the Kingdom of Heaven.
5.4: Blessed are they who mourn, for they will be comforted.
5.5: Blessed are they who are meek, for they will inherit the earth.
5.6: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be satisfied.
5.7: Blessed are they who show mercy, for mercies will be upon them.
5.8: Blessed are those who are pure in their hearts, for they shall see God.
5.9: Blessed are they who make peace, for they will be called the children of God.
5.10: Blessed are those who have been persecuted for the cause of righteousness, for theirs is the Kingdom of Heaven.
5.11: Blessed are you whenever they revile you and persecute you and they say every evil word against you for my sake, in falsehood.
5.12: Then rejoice and triumph, because your reward is great in Heaven, for just so they persecuted The Prophets who were before you.
5.13: You are the salt of the earth, but if salt becomes insipid, with what will it be salted? It is good for nothing except to be thrown outside and to be trodden upon by people.
5.14: You are the light of the world. You cannot hide a city that has been built upon a mountain.
5.15: And they do not light a lamp and set it under a basket, but on a lampstand, and it gives light to all those who are in the house.
5.16: Thus your light will shine before the children of men that they may see your good works, and may glorify your Father who is in Heaven.
5.17: Do not think that I have come to revoke The Written Law or The Prophets; I am not come to revoke but to fulfill.
5.18: Amen, I say to you that until Heaven and earth will pass away, one Yodh or one Taag and will not pass away from The Written Law until everything will happen.
5.19: Everyone therefore who violates one of these small commandments and will teach thus to the children of men will be called small in the Kingdom of Heaven, but everyone who will do and will teach the same will be called great in the Kingdom of Heaven.
5.20: For I say to you, that unless your goodness will exceed that of the Scribes and the Pharisees, you will not enter the Kingdom of Heaven.
5.21: You have heard that it was said to the ancients, “Do not murder, and whoever murders is condemned to judgment.”
5.22: But I am saying to you, that everyone who will be angry against his brother without cause is condemned before the judge, and everyone who will say to his brother, 'I spit on you', is condemned before the assembly, and whoever will say 'You fool.' is condemned to the Gehenna of fire.
5.23: If therefore you bring your offering to the altar, and there you remember that your brother holds any grudge against you,
5.24: Leave your offering there before the altar and go, first be reconciled with your brother, and then come, bring your offering.
5.25: Be allied with your plaintiff quickly, while you are with him in the street, lest the plaintiff delivers you to the judge and the judge delivers you to the Tax Collector and you fall into prison.
5.26: And truly I say to you, you will not come out from there until you give the last quarter cent.
5.27: You have heard that it was spoken, “You shall not commit adultery.”
5.28: But I am saying to you, everyone who looks at a woman so as to lust for her, immediately commits adultery with her in his heart.
5.29: But if your right eye subverts you, pluck it out and cast it from you, for it is profitable for you that your one member be lost, and not that your whole body should fall into Gehenna.
5.30: And if your right hand subverts you, cut it off, cast it from you, for it is profitable for you that one of your members be lost, and not that your whole body fall into Gehenna.
5.31: It has been said, “Whoever divorces his wife, let him give her a writing of divorce.”
5.32: But I am saying to you that everyone who divorces his wife, apart from the report of fornication, he causes her to commit adultery, and whoever takes her who is divorced is committing adultery.
5.33: Again you have heard that it was said to the ancients, “Do not lie in your oath, but you will fulfill to THE LORD JEHOVAH your oath.”
5.34: But I say to you, Do not swear at all, not by Heaven, for it is the throne of God
5.35: Neither by the earth, for it is his stool for his feet, nor by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.
5.36: Neither shall you swear by your head, because you cannot make in it a certain hair black or white.
5.37: But your statement shall be, “Yes, yes” and, “No, no”; anything more than these is from The Evil One.
5.38: You have heard that it was said, “An eye in exchange for an eye, and a tooth in exchange for a tooth.”
5.39: But I am saying to you, you shall not rise up against an evil person, but whoever strikes you on your right cheek, turn to him also the other.
5.40: And whoever wants to sue you and take your coat, leave for him also your cloak.
5.41: Whoever compels you to go one mile with him, go with him two miles.
5.42: Whoever asks you, give to him, and whoever wants to borrow from you, do not refuse him.
5.43: You have heard that it was said, “Show kindness to your neighbor and hate your enemy.”
5.44: But I say to you, love your enemies and bless the one who curses you, and do what is beautiful to the one who hates you, and pray over those who take you by force and persecute you.
5.45: So that you will become the children of your Father who is in Heaven, for his sun rises on the good and upon the evil and his rain descends on the just and on the unjust.
5.46: For if you love those who love you, what benefit is it to you? Behold, do not even the Tax Collectors the same thing?
5.47: And if you pray for the peace of your brethren only, what excellent thing are you doing? Behold, are not even the Tax Collectors doing the same thing?
5.48: Be therefore perfect, just as your Father who is in Heaven is perfect.”

6.1: Pay attention in your charity giving, that you do it not in front of people so that you may be seen by them, otherwise there is no reward for you with your Father in Heaven.
6.2: When therefore you do your charity giving, you should not blast a trumpet before you like the pretenders in the synagogues and in the streets, so that they may be glorified by the children of men; truly I say to you, they have received their reward.
6.3: But you, whenever you do charity giving, let not your left know what your right is doing.
6.4: So that your charity may be in secret, and your Father who sees in secret will reward you in public.
6.5: And when you pray, be not like the pretenders who like to stand in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets to pray, that they may be seen by the children of men, and truly I say to you, they have received their reward.
6.6: But you, when you pray, enter into your closet and lock your door, and pray to your father who is in secret, and your Father who sees in secret will reward you in public.
6.7: And whenever you are praying, you shall not be verbose like the heathen, for they think that they are heard by speaking much
6.8: Therefore you shall not be like them, for your Father knows what you need before you ask him.
6.9: Therefore pray in this way: 'Our Father who are in Heaven, hallowed be your name,
6.10: Let your Kingdom come, let your will be done also in the earth, just as it is in Heaven.
6.11: Give us our necessary bread today.
6.12: And forgive us our debts, just as we also forgive our debtors.
6.13: And lead us not to temptation but deliver us from evil, for yours is the Kingdom and the power and the glory, for the eternity of eternities.'
6.14: For if you forgive the children of men their faults, your Father who is in Heaven will also forgive you your faults.
6.15: But if you will not forgive the children of men, neither has your Father forgiven you your faults.
6.16: And when you are fasting, do not be gloomy like the pretenders, for they disfigure their faces, so that they may appear to the children of men to fast, and truly I say to you, that they have received their reward.
6.17: But you whenever you fast, wash your face and anoint your head.
6.18: So that you may not appear to the children of men to be fasting, but to your Father who is in secret, and your Father who sees in secret will reward you.
6.19: Do not place treasures for yourselves on the earth, where moths and corrosion disfigure and where thieves break in and steal.
6.20: But place treasures for yourselves in Heaven, where neither moths nor corrosion disfigure and where thieves neither break in nor steal.
6.21: For where your treasure is, there is your heart also.
6.22: But the lamp of the body is the eye; therefore if your eye shall be sound, your whole body also will be illuminated.
6.23: But if your eye shall be bad, your entire body will be darkness; if therefore the light that is in you is darkness, how great will be your darkness!
6.24: No man can work for two masters, for either he will hate one and will love the other, or he will honor one and the other he will ignore. You cannot work for God and for money.
6.25: Because of this I say to you, you shall not take pains for yourselves with what you will eat, or what you will drink, neither for your body, what you will put on; behold, is not the soul greater than food, and the body than clothing?
6.26: Behold the birds of the sky, that they neither sow nor reap, neither do they gather into barns, and your Father who is in Heaven sustains them; behold, are you not better than they?
6.27: But who of you, while taking pains, is able to add a foot and a half to his stature?
6.28: And why are you taking pains about clothing? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow without laboring or weaving.
6.29: But I say to you, not even Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these.
6.30: But if God so clothes the grass of the field that is today and will fall into the oven tomorrow, does he not multiply more to you, Oh small of faith?
6.31: Therefore do not be concerned or say, ''What will we eat?', or ''What will we drink?', or,''What will we wear'?
6.32: For the Gentiles are seeking all these things, but your Father who is in Heaven knows that all these things are necessary for you.
6.33: But seek first the Kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
6.34: Therefore you shall not be concerned about tomorrow, for tomorrow will be concerned for itself. A day's own trouble is sufficient for it.

7.1: You shall not judge, lest you be judged.
7.2: For with the judgment that you judge, you will be judged, and with the measure that you measure, it will be measured to you.
7.3: Why do you notice a chip that is in your brother's eye, and you do not observe the plank that is in your own eye?
7.4: Or how do you say to your brother, 'Let me cast out the chip from your eye', and behold, a plank is in your eye?
7.5: Hypocrite! First cast out the plank from your eye, and then you will see to cast out the chip from your brother's eye.
7.6: Do not give a sacrifice to dogs; neither throw your pearls before wild boars, lest they trample them with their feet, and return to run you through.
7.7: Ask and it will be given to you, seek and you will find, knock, and it will be opened to you.
7.8: For everyone who asks receives, and he who seeks finds, and to him who knocks it is opened.
7.9: And who is the man among you whose son will ask him for bread and will hand him a stone?
7.10: And if he will ask him for a fish, will he hand him a snake?
7.11: If therefore you who are evil know to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in Heaven give good things to those who ask him?
7.12: Everything whatsoever you desire that people should do for you, do likewise for them, for this is the Law and The Prophets.
7.13: Enter the narrow gate, for the gate is wide and the road is spacious which leads to destruction, and many are those who are going in it.
7.14: How narrow is the gate and strict the way that leads to life, and few are those who find it!
7.15: Beware of false Prophets who come to you in lambs' clothing, but from within they are plundering wolves.
7.16: But by their fruit you will know them. Do they gather grapes from thorns or figs from thistles?
7.17: So every good tree produces good fruit, but a bad tree produces bad fruit.
7.18: A good tree is not able to produce bad fruit, neither a bad tree to produce good fruit.
7.19: Every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and falls into the fire.
7.20: Therefore by their fruit you will know them.
7.21: It is not everyone that says to me, 'My Lord, my Lord'', who enters the Kingdom of Heaven, but whoever does the will of my Father who is in Heaven.
7.22: Many will say to me in that day, 'My Lord, my Lord, have we not prophesied in your name, and in your name have cast out demons, and have done many mighty works in your name?'
7.23: And then I will confess to them, 'I have never known you, remove yourselves far from me, you workers of evil.'
7.24: Everyone therefore who hears these my words, and does them, will be likened to the wise man who built his house on solid rock.
7.25: And the rain descended and the floods came and the wind blew, and they rushed against the house and it did not fall, for its foundation was laid on solid rock.
7.26: And everyone who hears these my words, but does not practice them, will be likened to the foolish man who built his house on sand.
7.27: And the rain descended and the floods came, and the wind blew, and they rushed against that house, and it fell, and its fall was great.”
7.28: And when Yeshua had finished these words, the crowds were marveling at his teaching.
7.29: For he was teaching them as one having authority and not as their Scribes and the Pharisees.

8.1: But when he came down from the mountain, great crowds followed him.
8.2: And behold a certain leper came worshiping him, and he said, “My lord, if you are willing, you are able to purify me.”
8.3: And Yeshua, stretching out his hand, touched him, and he said, “I am willing. Be purified”, and at that moment his leprosy was purged.
8.4: And Yeshua said to him, “Take heed that you speak to no one, but go shew yourself to the priest and bring a gift as Moses commanded for their testimony.
8.5: But when Yeshua entered Kapernahum, a certain Centurion approached him and he prayed to him.
8.6: And he said, “My Lord, my boy is lying in the house and is paralyzed and he is badly tormented.”
8.7: Yeshua said to him, “I shall come and heal him.”
8.8: That Centurion answered and said, “My lord, I am not worthy that you should enter under my roof, but only say in a word and my boy will be healed.”
8.9: “I also am a man under authority and soldiers are under my hand, and I say to this one, 'Go', and he goes, and to another, 'Come', and he comes, and to my servant, 'Do this', and he does.”
8.10: But when Yeshua heard, he was amazed, and he said to them that came with him, “Truly I say to you, that not even in Israel have I found faith like this.”
8.11: “But I say to you, that many will come from The East and from The West and will recline with Abraham and Isaaq and Jaqob in the Kingdom of Heaven.”
8.12: But the children of the Kingdom will be cast out to outer darkness; there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
8.13: And Yeshua said to that Centurion, “Go, it will be done for you just as you have believed”, and his boy was healed at that moment.
8.14: And Yeshua came to Shimeon's house, and he saw his mother-in-law who lay, and a fever had seized her.
8.15: And he touched her hand, and the fever left her, and she arose and she was waiting on him.
8.16: But when it was evening, they brought many demon possessed before him, and he cast their demons out with a word, and all those who had become ill, and he healed them.
8.17: So that would be fulfilled which was said by Isaiah the Prophet, who said: “He will take our pains and he will bear our sicknesses.”
8.18: But when Yeshua saw the great crowds surrounding him, he ordered that they go to the shore.
8.19: One scribe came near and said to him, “Rabbi, I shall come after you, wherever you go.”
8.20: Yeshua said to him, “Foxes have lairs and birds of the sky have shelters, but The Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.”
8.21: But another of his disciples said to him, “My Lord, allow me to first go bury my Father.”
8.22: But Yeshua said to him, “Come after me and let the dead bury their dead.”
8.23: And when Yeshua came up into the ship, his disciples came up with him.
8.24: And behold, a great earthquake occurred in the sea, so that the galley would be covered from the waves, but Yeshua was asleep.
8.25: And his disciples approached to awaken him and they were saying to him, “Our Lord, save us, we are being destroyed!”
8.26: And Yeshua said to them, “Why are you afraid, you small of faith?” Then he arose and rebuked the wind and the sea, and there was a great calm.
8.27: But the men were shocked and were saying, “Who is this, that the wind and the sea obey him?”
8.28: And when Yeshua came to the other side to the region of the Gadarenes, two demoniacs met him, who came out from the graveyard, extremely evil, so that no man could pass on that road.
8.29: And they cried out and they were saying, “What do we have to do with you, Yeshua, Son of God? Have you come here before the time to punish us?”
8.30: But there was distant from them a herd of many pigs grazing.
8.31: But those demons were begging him and saying, “If you cast us out, allow us to go into the herd of pigs.”
8.32: And Yeshua said to them, “Go”, and at once they came out and they entered into the pigs. And that whole herd went straight over the cliff and fell into the sea and died in the water.
8.33: But those who had been herding them fled and went to the city and revealed everything that had happened and about the demoniacs.
8.34: And the whole city came out to meet with Yeshua, and when they saw him, they begged him to depart from their borders.

9.1: And going up into the ship and crossing over he came to his city.
9.2: And they brought him a paralytic as he lay in the pallet, and Yeshua saw their faith, and he said to the paralytic, “Take heart my son, your sins are forgiven you.”
9.3: But some of the Scribes said among themselves, “This man blasphemes.”
9.4: But Yeshua knew their thinking, and he said to them, “Why do you think evil things in your heart?”
9.5: “For which is easier, to say, “Your sins are forgiven you”, or to say, “Arise and walk?”
9.6: But that you may know that The Son of Man has authority in the earth to forgive sins, I say to this paralytic, “Stand up, take your pallet and go to your house.”
9.7: And he stood up and he went to his house.
9.8: But when those crowds saw, they were awestruck, and they glorified God who gave authority like this to the children of men.
9.9: And when Yeshua passed by from there, he saw a man sitting at a tax collection booth, whose name was Mattay, and he said to him, “Come after me”, and rising, he went after him.
9.10: And when they reclined in the house, tax gatherers and many sinners came, and they reclined to eat with Yeshua and with his disciples.
9.11: And when the Pharisees saw, they were saying to his disciples, “Why does your master eat with Tax Collectors and sinners?”
9.12: But when Yeshua heard, he said to them, “The healthy do not need a doctor, but those who have become ill.”
9.13: “Go learn what this says, 'I require mercy and not a sacrifice', for I have not come to call the righteous but sinners.”
9.14: Then the disciples of Yohannan approached him, and they were saying, “Why are we and the Pharisees fasting much, and your disciples are not fasting?”
9.15: And Yeshua said to them, “How can the children of the bridal chamber fast as long as the groom is with them? But the days are coming when the groom will be taken from them and then they will fast.”
9.16: “No man places a new patch of cloth on an old coat, lest its fulness tears from that coat, and the rip would be greater.”
9.17: “Neither do they put new wine in old wineskins, lest the wineskins burst and the wine is spilled and the wineskins are destroyed; but they put new wine in new wineskins, and both are preserved.”
9.18: But as he was speaking these things with them, a certain ruler approached, bowing to him, and he said, “My daughter is dying even now, but come, lay your hand on her, and she will live.”
9.19: But Yeshua arose and his disciples and they went after him.
9.20: And behold a woman who had a flow of blood for twelve years, came from behind him and she touched the hem of his garment.
9.21: For she was saying in herself, “If only I may touch his clothes, I shall be healed.”
9.22: But Yeshua turned, and saw her, and he said to her, “Take heart my daughter, your faith has saved you.” And the woman was healed from that moment.
9.23: And Yeshua came to the house of the ruler, and he saw chanters and a crowd that was upset.
9.24: And he said to them. “Get out, for the girl is not dead, but she is asleep”, and they were laughing at him.
9.25: And when he had sent the crowd out, he entered, he took her by her hand, and the girl arose.
9.26: And this report went out into all that land.
9.27: And when Yeshua passed from there, two blind men followed him who cried out and they were saying, “Have pity on us, son of David.”
9.28: But when he had come to the house, those blind men came near to him; Yeshua said to them, “Do you believe that I am able to do this?” They were saying to him, “Yes, Our Lord.”
9.29: Then he touched their eyes, and he said, “Just as you have believed, let it be done to you.”
9.30: And at once their eyes were opened and Yeshua admonished them and he said, “See that no man will know it.”
9.31: But they went forth and they announced it in all that area.
9.32: And when Yeshua went out, they brought to him a deaf mute who had a demon upon him.
9.33: And when the demon went forth, that deaf-mute spoke, and the crowds were astonished, and they were saying, “Never has it been seen thus in Israel.”
9.34: But the Pharisees were saying, “By the prince of demons he casts out demons.”
9.35: And Yeshua was traveling about in all the cities and in the villages and he was teaching in their assemblies and preaching The Gospel of the Kingdom and was healing all diseases and all ailments.
9.36: But when Yeshua saw the crowds, he felt pity for them, for they were weary and wandering, like sheep without a shepherd.
9.37: And he said to his disciples, “The harvest is great, and the labourers are few.”
9.38: “Request therefore of The Lord of the harvest to send out laborers to his harvest.”

10.1: And he called his twelve disciples and he gave them authority over foul spirits to cast them out, and to heal every ailment and disease.
10.2: But the names of the twelve Apostles were these: the first of them, Shimeon who was called Kaypha, and Andraeus his brother, and Yaqob Bar Zebedee, and Yohannan his brother,
10.3: And Philippus, Bar Tolmay, and Thoma, and Mattay the Tax Collector, and Yaqob Bar Halphi, and Lebai who was called Thadi,
10.4: And Shimeon The Zealot, and Yehuda Skariota, he who betrayed him.
10.5: These twelve Yeshua sent and he commanded them and he said, “You shall not go by a road of the heathen and you shall not enter a city of the Samaritans.”
10.6: “But go especially to the sheep that have been lost of the house of Israel.”
10.7: “And as you are going, preach and say “The Kingdom of Heaven has come near.”
10.8: “Heal the sick, purify the lepers and cast out demons; freely you have received, freely give.”
10.9: “You shall not retain gold, neither silver, nor copper in your moneybags,”
10.10: “Neither wallet for the way, nor two coats, neither shoes, nor staff, for a laborer is worthy of his provisions.”
10.11: “Whichever city or village you enter, ask who is worthy in it and stay there until you leave.”
10.12: “And when you enter a household, invoke the peace of the household.”
10.13: “And if that household is worthy, your blessing of peace will come upon it, but if not, your blessing of peace will return unto you.”
10.14: “But whoever does not receive you, neither listens to your words, when you depart from the house or from the village, shake the sand from your feet.”
10.15: “And truly I say to you, it will be tranquil in the day of judgment for the land of Sadom and Ammora compared to that city.”
10.16: “Behold, I am sending you as lambs among wolves; be therefore crafty as snakes and innocent as doves.”
10.17: “But beware of the children of men, for they will deliver you to the courts and they will scourge you in their synagogues.”
10.18: “And they will bring you before Governors and Kings because of me, for their testimony and that of the Gentiles.”
10.19: “But when they arrest you, do not be anxious how or what you will speak, for it will be given to you in that hour what you should say.”
10.20: “For it will not be you speaking, but The Spirit of your Father speaking in you.”
10.21: “But brother will deliver his brother to death, and a father his son, and children will rise against their parents and will put them to death.”
10.22: “And you will be hated by everyone because of my name, but whoever will endure until the end, he will be saved.”
10.23: “But when they persecute you in this city, flee to another, for truly I say to you, you will not have finished all the cities of the house of Israel until The Son of Man come.”
10.24: “No disciple is greater than his master, neither a servant than his lord.”
10.25: “It is enough for a disciple to be like his master and for a servant to be like his lord. If they have called the lord of the house Beelzebub, how much more the children of his household?”
10.26: “Therefore you shall not be afraid of them, for there is nothing covered that will not be revealed, and hidden, that will not be known.”
10.27: “Whatever I tell you in the darkness, say it in the light, and whatever you hear with your ears, preach on the rooftops.”
10.28: “And you shall not be afraid of those who kill the body that are not able to kill the soul; rather be afraid of him who can destroy soul and body in Gehenna.”
10.29: “Are not two sparrows sold for a penny, and not one of them falls to the ground apart from your Father?”
10.30: “But your hairs of your head are all numbered.”
10.31: “You shall not be afraid, therefore; you are better than many sparrows.”
10.32: “Everyone, therefore, who will confess me before children of men, I shall confess him also before my Father who is in Heaven.
10.33: But whoever will deny me before the children of men, I shall deny him also before my Father who is in Heaven.
10.34: Think not that I have come to bring peace in the earth; I have not come to bring peace, but a sword.
10.35: I have come to divide a man against his father and a daughter against her mother and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law,
10.36: And a man's enemies will be the members of his household.
10.37: Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me; and whoever loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
10.38: And everyone who does not take his cross and come after me is not worthy of me.
10.39: Whoever will lose his life for my sake will find it; whoever will find his life will lose it.
10.40: Whoever receives you receives me, and whoever receives me receives him who sent me.
10.41: Whoever receives a Prophet in the name of a Prophet receives the reward of the Prophet, and whoever receives The Righteous One in the name of The Righteous One receives the reward of The Righteous One.
10.42: “And everyone who gives one of these little ones a cup of cold water only to drink, in the name of a disciple, amen, I say to you, he will not lose his reward.”

11.1: So it was that when Yeshua had finished charging his twelve disciples he moved from there to teach and to preach in their cities.
11.2: But when Yohannan had heard in prison of the works of The Messiah, he sent by his disciples,
11.3: And he said to him, “Are you he who comes, or is it another we expect?”
11.4: Yeshua answered and he said to them, “Go relate to Yohannan those things that you hear and see.”
11.5: “Those who were blind see, and those who were lame walk, and lepers are being purified, and those once deaf are hearing, and those who died are rising and those who were poor are given The Good News.”
11.6: “And blessed is he who will not be suspicious of me.”
11.7: But when they departed, Yeshua began to say to the crowds about Yohannan, “What did you go out to the wilderness to see, a reed shaken by the wind?”
11.8: “Otherwise, what did you go out to see; a man who wears a long soft robe? Behold those who wear soft things are in the house of the King.”
11.9: “Otherwise what did you go out to see? A Prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a Prophet.”
11.10: “For this is he about whom it is written: 'Behold, I am sending my messenger before your presence that he may prepare the road before you.' “
11.11: “Amen, I say to you, that among them born of women there has not arisen a greater than Yohannan The Baptizer, but a little one in the Kingdom of Heaven is greater than he.”
11.12: “From the days of Yohannan The Baptizer until this hour the Kingdom of Heaven is led by force and the violent are seizing it.”
11.13: “All The Prophets and The Written Law have prophesied until Yohannan.
11.14: And if you will, he is Elijah who was to come.
11.15: Whoever has an ear to hear, let him hear.
11.16: But to what shall I liken this generation? It is like children sitting in the street and calling their playmates,
11.17: And saying, 'We sang to you, and you did not dance, and we cried for you, and you were not sad.'
11.18: For Yohannan came who ate nothing and drank nothing, and they said: 'He has a demon.'
11.19: The Son of Man came eating and drinking and they said, 'Behold the man is a glutton and a wine drinker, a friend of Tax Collectors and of sinners.' And wisdom is justified by its works.”
11.20: Then Yeshua began to reproach those cities in which his many mighty works had occurred, and they did not repent.
11.21: And he said, “Woe to you Chorazin, woe to you Bythsaida, for if those powerful works which have occurred in you had occurred in Tsur and Tsidon, they doubtless would have repented in sackcloth and in ashes.
11.22: Yet I say to you, that for Tsur and for Tsidon it will be tranquil in the day of judgment compared to you.
11.23: And you Kapernahum, which have been exalted unto Heaven, you will descend unto Sheol, for if the mighty works had been done in Sadom, which have been done in you, it would have remained until today.
11.24: But I say to you, it will be tranquil for the land of Sadom in the Day of Judgment compared to you.”
11.25: At that time Yeshua answered and said, “I thank you my Father, Lord of Heaven and Earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and the intelligent and you have revealed them to infants.
11.26: Yes, my Father, for so it was desirable before you.
11.27: Everything has been given up to me by my Father and no man knows The Son except The Father only; also no man knows The Father except The Son only, and he to whom The Son desires to reveal him.
11.28: Come unto me, all of you who labor and are forced to bear burdens, and I shall give you rest.
11.29: Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am peaceful and meek in my heart and you will find rest for your souls.
11.30: For my yoke is pleasant and my burden is light.”

12.1: At that time Yeshua was walking on the Sabbath in the grainfields, and his disciples were hungry and they began plucking the ears of grain and they were eating.
12.2: But when the Pharisees saw them, they were saying to him, “Behold, your disciples are doing something that is illegal to do on the Sabbath.”
12.3: But he said to them, “Have you not read what David did when he was hungry and those who were with him?
12.4: How he entered the house of God, and he ate the bread of the table of THE LORD JEHOVAH, that which was not legal for him to eat, neither for those who were with him, but rather for the priests only?
12.5: Or have you not read in The Written Law that the priests in The Temple profane the Sabbath and are blameless?
12.6: But I say to you, one greater than The Temple is here.
12.7: But if you had known what this is, 'I want mercy and not a sacrifice', you would not have condemned those who are blameless.
12.8: For The Son of Man is Master of the Sabbath.”
12.9: And Yeshua departed from there and he came to their synagogue.
12.10: One man was there whose hand was withered, and they were asking him, and they were saying, “Is it legal To heal on the Sabbath”, so that They might accuse him.
12.11: He said to them, “Who is the man among you who has one sheep, and if it falls into a pit on the Sabbath day, will not take hold and lift it out?”
12.12: “How much greater is a man than a sheep? Therefore it is legal to do good on the Sabbath.”
12.13: And then he said to that man, “Stretch out your hand”, and he stretched out his hand and it was restored like his other.
12.14: And the Pharisees went out and they took council against him so that they might destroy him.
12.15: But Yeshua knew, and he moved from there, and great crowds went after him and he healed all of them.
12.16: And he warned them that they should not reveal him.
12.17: That the thing would be fulfilled that was spoken by Isaiah the Prophet which says:
12.18: “Behold, my servant, in whom I delight, my beloved, for whom my soul has longed, I shall put my Spirit upon him, and he will preach judgment to the nations.
12.19: He will not dispute neither will he cry out, nor will a man hear his voice in the streets.
12.20: He will not break off a fractured reed, and the lamp that flickers he will not extinguish until he will bring the verdict of innocence,
12.21: And in his name the nations will hope.”
12.22: But then they brought to him a certain demoniac, mute and blind, and he healed him so that the mute and blind man could speak and could see.
12.23: And all the crowds were astounded and they were saying, “Is this not The Son of David?”
12.24: But the Pharisees, when they heard, they were saying, “This one does not cast out demons except by Beelzebub the prince of demons.”
12.25: But Yeshua knew their designs, and he said to them, “Every Kingdom that is divided against itself will be destroyed and every house and city that is divided against itself will not stand.
12.26: And if Satan casts out Satan, he has been divided against himself; how therefore will his Kingdom stand?
12.27: And if I am casting out demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they will be your judges.
12.28: And if I am casting out demons by The Spirit of God, the Kingdom of God has come near to you.
12.29: For how can a man enter the house of the mighty man and plunder his goods unless first he bind the mighty man? Then he may plunder his house.
12.30: Whoever is not with me is against me; whoever does not gather with me truly is scattering.
12.31: Therefore I say to you, all sins and blasphemies will be forgiven to the children of men, but the blasphemy that is against The Spirit will not be forgiven to the children of men.
12.32: Everyone who will say a word against The Son of Man, it will be forgiven him, but whoever will speak against The Spirit of Holiness, it will not be forgiven to him, not in this world, neither in the world that is being prepared.
12.33: Either make the tree good and its fruit good or make the tree bad and its fruit bad, for the tree is known by its fruit.
12.34: Offspring of vipers! How can you who are evil speak good things? For from the fulness of the heart the mouth speaks.
12.35: A good man from a good treasure brings good things, and an evil man from evil treasure brings evil things.
12.36: For I say to you that every idle word that people will speak, they will give an answer for it in the Day of Judgment.
12.37: For by your words you will be justified and by your words you will be condemned.”
12.38: Then some of the Scribes and Pharisees responded and they were saying to him, “Teacher we wish to see a sign from you.”
12.39: But he answered and said to them, “An evil and adulterous generation seeks a sign and a sign will not be given to it except the sign of Jonah the Prophet.
12.40: For just as Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights, thus The Son of Man will be in the heart of the earth three days and three nights.
12.41: The Ninevite men will arise in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, for they repented at the preaching of Jonah, and behold, one greater than Jonah is here.
12.42: The queen of The South will arise in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and behold, one greater than Solomon is here.
12.43: But whenever a foul spirit goes out from a man, it wanders about in places without water in them, and it seeks rest and does not find it.
12.44: Then it says, 'I shall return to my house from where I came out', and it goes finding that it is empty, swept and decorated.
12.45: Then it goes bringing with it seven other spirits worse than itself, and they enter and dwell there, and the end of that man becomes worse than his beginning. Thus will it be done to this evil generation.”
12.46: But while he was speaking to the crowds, his mother and his brothers came standing outside and desired to speak with him.
12.47: And a man said to him, “Behold, your mother and your brothers are standing outside and want to speak with you.”
12.48: But he answered and said to him who told him, “Who is my mother and who are my brothers?”
12.49: And he stretched his hands toward his disciples and said, “Behold my mother and behold my brothers!”
12.50: “For everyone who does the will of my Father who is in Heaven, the same is my brother and my sister and my mother.”

13.1: But that day Yeshua went out from the house and he sat down by the seaside.
13.2: And great crowds were assembled to him so that he embarked, seating himself in a ship, and all the crowds were standing on the beach by the sea.
13.3: And he was speaking much with them in parables and he said, “Behold, a sower went out to sow.
13.4: But as he sowed, some seed fell on the side of the road and a bird came and ate it.
13.5: And others fell on the rock where there was not much soil, and within the hour it sprouted because there was no depth of soil.
13.6: But when the sun rose, it became hot, and because there were no roots, it dried up.
13.7: And others fell among the thorns and the thorns came up and choked it.
13.8: And others fell in the good soil and it yielded fruit, some an hundredfold and some sixtyfold and some thirtyfold.
13.9: Whoever has an ear that hears, let him hear.”
13.10: And his disciples approached and they were saying to him, “Why are you speaking with them in parables?”
13.11: But he answered and said to them: “It has been given to you to know the secrets of the Kingdom of Heaven, but to them it has not been given.
13.12: For to one who has it, it will be given, and it will be increased.
13.13: And from him who has it not, will be taken even that which he has, therefore I am speaking to them in parables because they who see do not see, and those who hear neither hear nor understand.
13.14: And the prophecy of Isaiah is fulfilled in them, which says, 'Hearing you will hear, and you will not understand, and seeing you will see and you will not know.
13.15: For the heart of this people has become dense, and they have hardly heard with their ears and their eyes they have shut, lest they would see with their eyes and they would hear with their ears and they would understand in their hearts and they would be converted and I would heal them.'
13.16: But you have blessings to your eyes, for they are seeing, and to your ears, for they are hearing.
13.17: For I say to you that many Prophets and righteous ones have yearned to see the things that you are seeing and they did not see them, and to hear the things that you are hearing, and they did not hear them.
13.18: But hear the parable of the seed.
13.19: Everyone who hears the word of the Kingdom and does not understand, The Evil One comes into him and snatches the word that was sown in his heart; this is that which was sown upon the roadside.
13.20: But that which was sown upon the rock is the one who hears the word, and immediately with joy he receives it.
13.21: But there are no roots in him, but he is temporal, and when there is distress or persecution because of the word, immediately he falls apart.
13.22: That which was sown among the thorns is the one who hears the word, and the cares of this world and the deception of wealth choke the word, and that one is fruitless.
13.23: But that which was sown on the good soil is he who hears my word and understands and he yields fruit, and produces some by the hundreds and some by sixty's and some by thirty's.”
13.24: He told them another parable and he said, “The Kingdom of Heaven is likened to the man who sowed good seed in his field.
13.25: And while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and he left.
13.26: But when the grass sprouted, it produced fruit; then the tares also appeared.
13.27: And the servants of the Lord of the house approached and said to him, 'Our Lord, did you not sow good seed in your field? From where are the tares in it?'
13.28: But he said to them, 'An enemy has done this'; his servants said to him, 'Do you want us to go select them out?'
13.29: But he said to them, 'When you collect the tares, would you not uproot the wheat with them?'
13.30: 'Let both grow together until the harvest and in the time of the harvest, I shall say to the reapers, “Select out the tares first and bind them into bundles to burn, but gather the wheat to my granary.”'
13.31: He told another parable to them and said, “The Kingdom of Heaven is likened to a grain of mustard seed which a man had taken and sown in his field.
13.32: And this is the smallest of all seeds, but whenever it has grown, it is greatest of all small herbs and it becomes a tree so that a bird of the sky may come settle in its branches.”
13.33: He told them another parable: “The Kingdom of Heaven is likened to leaven which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal until all of it had fermented.”
13.34: Yeshua spoke all these things in parables to the crowds and without a parable he was not speaking with them.
13.35: So that the thing that was spoken by the Prophet would be fulfilled which says, “I shall open my mouth in parables and I shall declare things hidden from before the foundation of the world.”
13.36: Then Yeshua left the crowds and came to the house and his disciples came to him and they were saying to him, “Explain to us that parable of the tares and of the field.”
13.37: But he answered and said to them, “He who sowed the good seed is The Son of Man.
13.38: The field is the world but the good seed is the children of the Kingdom and the tares are the children of The Evil One.
13.39: The enemy who sowed them is Satan, but the harvest is the end of the world and the reapers are the Angels.
13.40: Therefore, just as the tares are gathered and burn in the fire, so it will be in the end of this world.
13.41: The Son of Man will send his Angels and they will select from his Kingdom all of those stumbling blocks and all of those evil doers.
13.42: And they will cast them into the essence of fire; there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
13.43: Then the righteous will shine as the sun in the Kingdom of their Father. Whoever has an ear that will hear, let him hear.
13.44: Again the Kingdom of Heaven is likened to treasure that was hidden in a field which a man found and hid, and for his joy he went selling everything that he had and he bought that field.
13.45: But again the Kingdom of Heaven is likened to the merchant man who was searching for precious pearls.
13.46: But when he found a certain obviously valuable pearl, he went and sold everything he had and bought it.
13.47: Again the Kingdom of Heaven is like a net that was cast into the sea, and it collected from every kind.
13.48: But when it was full they brought it up to the seashore, and they sat and selected out and they placed the good in vessels and the bad they threw out.
13.49: Thus it will be in the end of the world. The Angels will go forth and they will separate the wicked from among the righteous.
13.50: And they will cast them into the essence of fire; there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
13.51: Yeshua said to them, “Have you understood all these things?” They were saying to him, “Yes, Our Lord.”
13.52: He said to them, “And because of this, every scribe who is instructed for the Kingdom of Heaven is like the man, a house owner, who brings from his treasure new and old things.”
13.53: And it was that when Yeshua had finished these parables, he departed from there.
13.54: And he came to his city and he taught them in their synagogues so that they would marvel and they would say, “From where does he have this wisdom and the miracles?”
13.55: “Is not this the carpenter's son? Is not his mother called Maryam, and his brothers, Yaqob and Yose and Shimeon and Yehudah?”
13.56: “And are not all his sisters with us? From where does he have all these things?”
13.57: And they were suspicious of him; but Yeshua said to them, “There is no Prophet who is despised except in his city and in his home.”
13.58: And he did not do many miracles there because of their suspicion. Matthew

14.1: But at that time Herodus the Tetrarch heard of the fame of Yeshua.
14.2: And he said to his servants, “This is Yohannan The Baptizer; but he has arisen from the grave, therefore miracles are done by him.”
14.3: For Herodus had seized Yohannan and bound him and cast him into prison because of Herodia the wife of Philippus his brother.
14.4: For Yohannan had said to him, “It is not lawful that she should be your wife.”
14.5: And he had wanted to kill him and he was afraid of the people who were holding him as a Prophet.
14.6: But when Herodus' birthday came, the daughter of Herodia danced before the dinner guests and she pleased Herodus.
14.7: Because of this, he swore an oath to her that he would give her anything that she would ask.
14.8: But because she had been instructed by her mother, she had said, “Give me here in a dish the head of Yohannan The Baptizer.”
14.9: And it saddened the King, but because of the oath and the guests, he commanded that it be given to her.
14.10: And he sent, cutting off the head of Yohannan in the prison.
14.11: And his head was brought in a dish and it was given to the girl and she brought it to her mother.
14.12: And his disciples came, took his corpse, performed a burial and came and informed Yeshua.
14.13: But when Yeshua heard, he departed from there by ship to a desert region alone, and when the crowds heard, they went after him by land from the cities.
14.14: And Yeshua came down, seeing the great crowds, and he was moved with pity for them and he healed their sick.
14.15: When it was evening, his disciples came to join him and they said to him, “This is a desert place and the time is late. Dismiss the crowds of people so they will go to the villages and buy food for themselves.”
14.16: But he said to them, “It is not necessary for them to go. You give them to eat.”
14.17: But they said to him, “There is nothing here with us but five loaves and two fish.”
14.18: But Yeshua said to them, “Bring them here to me.”
14.19: And he commanded the crowds to recline on the ground and he took those five loaves and two fish and he gazed into Heaven and he blessed and he broke and he gave to his disciples and the disciples placed those things before the crowds.
14.20: And they all ate and were satisfied and they collected the remainder of the fragments twelve baskets full.
14.21: But those men who ate were 5,000, apart from the women and children.
14.22: And at once he compelled his disciples to embark the ship and to go before him to the other side while he sent the crowds away.
14.23: And when he had sent the crowds away, he went up to a mountain alone to pray and when it was dark he was there alone.
14.24: And the ship was many furlongs distant from the land while it was tossed greatly by the waves, for the wind was against it.
14.25: But in the fourth watch of the night, Yeshua came unto them while he was walking on the water.
14.26: And his disciples saw him, that he was walking on the water, and they were alarmed and they were saying, “It is an illusion!”, and they cried out in fear.
14.27: But Yeshua immediately spoke with them and he said, “Take heart; I AM THE LIVING GOD. Do not be afraid.”
14.28: And Kaypha answered and he said to him, “My Lord, if you are He, command me to come unto you on the water.”
14.29: And Yeshua said to him, “Come”, and Kaypha went down from the ship and he walked on the water to come to Yeshua.
14.30: And when he saw the wind was violent, he was afraid, and he began to sink, and he raised his voice and he said, “My Lord, save me!”
14.31: And immediately our Lord stretched out his hand and he held him and said to him, “Oh small of faith! Why did you doubt?”
14.32: And when they came up into the ship the wind stopped.
14.33: And those who were in the ship came and they worshiped him, and they said, “Truly, you are The Son of God!”
14.34: And they traveled and they came to the land of Genessar.
14.35: And the men of that place recognized him and they sent to all the villages around them and brought all of those who were very sick to him.
14.36: And they were begging him that they may touch if only the hem of his garment, and those who touched were healed.

15.1: And the Pharisees and the Scribes who were from Jerusalem came unto Yeshua and they were saying:
15.2: “Why do your disciples violate the tradition of the Elders? They do not wash their hands whenever they eat bread.”
15.3: Yeshua answered and said to them, “Why do you also violate the commandment of God for the sake of your traditions?”
15.4: “For God has said, 'Honour your father and your mother,' and 'Whoever reviles his father and his mother shall surely die.'”
15.5: “Now you are saying, 'Everyone who will say to father or mother, 'My offering is anything by which you made a profit from me', should honor neither his father nor his mother.”
15.6: “And you nullify the word of God because of your traditions.”
15.7: “Phonies! Isaiah prophesied well against you and said:”
15.8: 'This people is honouring me with their lips but their heart is very far from me.'
15.9: 'And they revere me in vain while they teach the doctrines of the commandments of man.' “
15.10: And he called the crowds and he said to them, “Hear and understand.”
15.11: “It is not the thing that enters the mouth that defiles a man, but the thing that proceeds from the mouth that defiles a man.”
15.12: Then his disciples approached and they were saying to him, “Do you know that the Pharisees who heard this saying were indignant?”
15.13: But he answered and said to them, “Every plant that my Father who is in Heaven has not planted will be uprooted.”
15.14: “Let them alone. They are blind guides of the blind; but if a blind man leads a blind man, both will fall into a pit.”
15.15: And Shimeon Kaypha answered and said to him: “My Lord, explain to us this parable.”
15.16: But he said to them, “Are you still also not understanding?”
15.17: “Do you not know that anything that enters the mouth goes to the belly and is cast out from there in excretion?”
15.18: “Anything that proceeds from the mouth proceeds from the heart and it defiles the man.”
15.19: “For from the heart proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, murders, fornications, thefts, lying testimonies, blasphemies.”
15.20: “These things are those that defile a man, but if a man will eat after not washing his hands, he is not defiled.”
15.21: But Yeshua went out from there and he came to the borders of Tsur and of Tsidon.
15.22: And behold a Canaanitess woman from those borders came forth crying out and she said, “Have pity on me my lord, son of David, my daughter is badly driven by a demon.”
15.23: But he did not give her an answer, and his disciples came and begged him, and they were saying, “Send her away, for she is crying after us.”
15.24: But he answered and said to them, “I am not sent except to the sheep that have strayed from the house of Israel.”
15.25: But she came and worshiped him and she said, “My Lord, help me.”
15.26: He said to her, “It is not good to take the children's bread and cast it to the dogs.”
15.27: But she said, “Yes, my lord, even the dogs eat from the crumbs that fall from their master's table and they live.”
15.28: But then Yeshua said to her, “O woman, great is your faith; it will be done for you as you will.” And her daughter was healed from that moment.
15.29: And Yeshua departed from there and he came by the seaside of Galilee and he went up the mountain and sat down there.
15.30: Many crowds came to him who had the lame and the blind and dumb and the crippled and many others, and they laid them at the feet of Yeshua and he healed them.
15.31: So that the crowds would be amazed who saw those who had been mute speaking, and those who had been crippled who were healed, and those who had been lame walking, and those who had been blind who were seeing, and they glorified the God of Israel.
15.32: Then Yeshua called his disciples and said to them: “I am moved with pity for this multitude; they have remained with me three days and they have nothing to eat, and I am not willing to send them away fasting, lest they should faint in the road.”
15.33: His disciples were saying to him, “Where is bread for us in the wilderness that will satisfy this whole crowd?
15.34: Yeshua said to them, “How many loaves do you have?” And they said to him, “Seven, and a few small fish.”
15.35: And he ordered the crowd to sit for a meal on the ground.
15.36: And he took up those seven loaves and the fish and he gave praise, and he broke and he gave to his disciples and his disciples gave to the crowd.
15.37: And all of them ate and were satisfied and they took up the remnants of fragments, filling seven baskets.
15.38: But they who ate had been 4,000 men, apart from women and children.
15.39: And when he sent the crowds away, he went up into the ship and he came to the border of Magdo.

16.1: And the Pharisees and the Sadducees approached, testing him and asking him to show them a sign from Heaven.
16.2: But he answered and said to them, “Whenever it is evening you say, 'It will be fair weather, for the sky is red'.”
16.3: “And in the morning you say, 'There will be a storm today, for the sky is gloomily red.' Respecters of persons! You know how to observe the appearance of the sky; do you not know how to distinguish the signs of this time?”
16.4: “A wicked and adulterous generation seeks a sign, and a sign is not given to it, but the sign of Jonah The Prophet.” And he left them and departed.
16.5: And when his disciples came to the other side, they had forgotten to take bread with them.
16.6: And he said to them, “Take heed; beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.”
16.7: But they were reasoning among themselves, and they were saying it was because they had not taken bread.
16.8: But Yeshua knew and said to them, “Oh, small of faith! Why do you think among yourselves it was because you have not taken bread?”
16.9: “Have you not yet understood? Do you not remember those five loaves of the 5,000? How many large baskets did you take up?”
16.10: “Neither those seven loaves of the 4,000 and how many round baskets you took up?”
16.11: “But how do you not understand that it was not about bread that I spoke to you, but to beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the Sadducees?”
16.12: But then they understood that he did not say to beware of the leaven of bread, but of the teaching of Pharisees and of the Sadducees.
16.13: But when Yeshua came to the region of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, “What is it people say about me that I The Son of Man am?”
16.14: But they said, “ Some say Yohannan The Baptizer, but others Elijah, and others Jeremiah or one of The Prophets.”
16.15: But he said to them, “Who is it you say that I am?”
16.16: Shimeon Kaypha answered, “You are The Messiah, The Son of THE LIVING GOD”.
16.17: Yeshua answered and said to him, “You are Blessed, Shimeon Bar Yona, because flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father who is in Heaven.”
16.18: “Also I say to you, that you are Kaypha, and upon this stone I shall build my church, and the gates of Sheol will not withstand it.”
16.19: “To you I shall give the keys of the Kingdom of Heaven; everything that you will bind in the earth will have been bound in Heaven, and anything that you will release in the earth will have been released in Heaven.”
16.20: Then he ordered his disciples to tell no man that he is The Messiah.
16.21: And from then Yeshua began to inform his disciples that he was prepared to go to Jerusalem and he would suffer many things from the Elders and from the Chief Priests and the Scribes and he would be murdered, and the third day he would rise.
16.22: And Kaypha took him aside and he began to rebuke him, and he said, “ Far be it from you, my Lord, that this should happen to you.”
16.23: But he turned and said to Kaypha, “Get behind me, Satan; you are a stumbling block to me because you do not reason of God but of humans.”
16.24: Then Yeshua said to his disciples, “Whoever wants to come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and let him come after me.”
16.25: “For whoever wills to save his life will lose it and whoever will lose his life for me will find it.”
16.26: “For what does a person benefit if he gains the whole world and lacks his soul? Or what will a person give to regain his soul?
16.27: For The Son of Man is going to come in the glory of his Father with the Holy Angels and then he will repay each man according to his works.
16.28: Amen, I say to you, that there are men who are standing here who will not taste death until they will see The Son of Man who comes with his Kingdom.” Matthew

17.1: And after six days Yeshua took Kaypha, Yaqob and Yohannan his brother and brought them up to a high mountain by themselves.
17.2: And Yeshua was transformed before them and his face shone like the sun but his garments became white like light.
17.3: And Moses and Elijah appeared to them as they were speaking with him.
17.4: But Kaypha answered and said to Yeshua, “My Lord, it is beautiful for us that we should be here, and if you wish, we will make here three booths, one for you and one for Moses and one for Elijah.”
17.5: And while he was speaking, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them and a voice came from the cloud, which said, “This is my Son, The Beloved, in whom I delight; hear him.”
17.6: And when the disciples heard, they fell on their faces, and they were very afraid.
17.7: And Yeshua came to them and he touched them and said, “Arise, do not be afraid.”
17.8: And they lifted their eyes and did not see anyone except Yeshua by himself.
17.9: And as they descended from the mountain, Yeshua ordered them and he said to them, “Do not tell this vision in the presence of any man until The Son of Man will rise from the dead.”
17.10: And his disciples asked him and they were saying to him, “Why do the Scribes therefore say that Elijah must come first?”
17.11: Yeshua answered and he said to them, “Elijah does come first so that everything may end.”
17.12: But I say to you, behold, Elijah has come, and they did not know him, and they have done unto him everything whatsoever they wished; likewise also The Son of Man is going to suffer from them.
17.13: Then the disciples understood that he spoke to them about Yohannan The Baptizer.
17.14: And when they came to the multitude, a man came unto him and knelt on his knees.
17.15: And he said to him, “My lord, have mercy on me, my son has a lunatic demon and has become ill, for he has fallen many times into fire and many times into water.”
17.16: “And I brought him to your disciples and they were not able to heal him.”
17.17: Yeshua answered and he said, “Oh, faithless and twisted generation! How long shall I be with you, and how long shall I endure you? Bring him here to me.”
17.18: And Yeshua rebuked it and the demon went out from him and The Boy was healed from that moment.
17.19: Then the disciples came to Yeshua himself alone and they said to him, “Why were we not able to heal him?”
17.20: Yeshua said to them, “Because of your unbelief, for amen, I say to you, that if you had faith like a grain of mustard seed, you may say to this mountain, 'Move from here', and it will move, and nothing will be difficult for you”.
17.21: “But this kind does not go out except by fasting and by prayer.”
17.22: When they were traveling in Galilee, Yeshua said to them, “The Son of Man will be betrayed to the hands of men.
17.23: And they will murder him, and the third day he will arise.”And it grieved them greatly.
17.24: And when they came to Kapernahum, those who take the two-each quarter-shekels head tax came to Kaypha and said to him: “Does not your Rabbi pay the two quarter-shekels?”
17.25: And he said to them, “Yes.” And when Kaypha entered the house, Yeshua anticipated him and he said to him, “How does it seem to you Shimeon? From whom do the Kings of the earth take taxes and head money? From their children or from strangers?”
17.26: And Shimeon said to him, “From strangers.” Then Yeshua said to him, “Then the children are free.”
17.27: “But lest we give offense to them, go to the sea and cast a fish hook, and the first fish that comes up, open its mouth and you will find a shekel. Take that and give for me and for you.”

18.1: And in that hour the disciples approached to join Yeshua and they were saying, “Who is truly the greatest in the Kingdom of Heaven?”
18.2: And Yeshua called a boy and stood him in their midst.
18.3: And he said, “Truly I say to you, unless you will be converted and become like children, you will not enter the Kingdom of Heaven.”
18.4: “Whoever therefore humbles himself like this boy, he will be greatest in the Kingdom of Heaven.”
18.5: “And whoever will receive one such as this boy, in my name, receives me.”
18.6: “And everyone who commits an offense against one of these little ones who believe in me, it were profitable for him that a donkey's millstone would be hung around his neck and he be sunk in the depths of the sea.”
18.7: “Woe to the world because of offenses, for it is necessary that offenses will come, but woe to the man by whom the offenses will come.”
18.8: “But if your hand or your foot subverts you, cut it off and cast it from you, for it is better for you that you enter life as lame or as maimed, rather than having two hands or two feet, that you would fall into eternal fire.”
18.9: “And if your eye subverts you, pull it out and throw it from you, for it is better for you that you would enter life with one eye, rather than having two eyes, that you would fall into The Gehenna of fire.
18.10: Take heed that you do not despise one of these little ones, for I say to you that their Angels in Heaven do always see the face of my Father who is in Heaven.
18.11: For The Son of Man has come to save whatever has been lost.
18.12: How does it seem to you? If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them will go astray, does he not leave the ninety-nine in the mountain and go on searching for that lost one?
18.13: And if he should find it, certainly I say to you, that he rejoices in it more than in the ninety-nine that did not stray.
18.14: Just so, it is not the will before your Father who is in Heaven that one of these little ones should perish.
18.15: But if your brother wrongs you, reprove him between you and him alone; if he hears you, you have gained your brother.
18.16: And if he does not hear you, take one or two with you, that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word will be established.
18.17: But if he will not hear them, tell the assembly, and if he does not hear the assembly, let him be to you as a tax gatherer and as a heathen.
18.18: And truly I say to you, everything whatsoever you will bind in the earth will have been bound in Heaven, and anything that you will release in the earth will have been released in Heaven.
18.19: Again I say to you, that if two of you will agree in the earth about any matter which they will request, it will be done for them from the presence of my Father who is in Heaven.
18.20: For where two or three are assembled in my name, there am I in the midst of them.”
18.21: Then Kaypha approached him, and he said, “My Lord, “If my brother commits an offense against me, how many times shall I forgive him? Seven times?”
18.22: And Yeshua said to him, “I do not say to you until seven times, but until seventy times seven each.
18.23: Therefore the Kingdom of Heaven is compared to a man who was a King, wanting to take an account of his servants.
18.24: And when he began to take it, they brought him one who owed 10,000 talents.
18.25: And when he had nothing to pay, his lord commanded that he would be sold, and his wife and his children, and everything that he had, and he would pay.
18.26: And falling down, that servant worshiped him, and he said, “My Lord, be patient with me, and I shall pay you everything.”
18.27: And the lord of that servant was moved with pity, and he released him, forgiving his debt.
18.28: But that servant went out and found one of his associates who had owed him a hundred denarii, and he seized him and throttled him, and he said to him, “Give me that which you owe me.”
18.29: And that associate fell down before his feet, begging him and saying to him, “Be patient with me and I shall pay you.”
18.30: But he was not willing, but he went and he cast him into prison until he would give him whatever he owed him.
18.31: But when their associates saw all what happened, it was very grievous to them, and they came and revealed to their lord everything that had happened.
18.32: Then his lord called him, and said to him, “You wicked servant, I forgave you that entire debt because you begged me.”
18.33: “Was it not incumbent upon you also for you to have mercy on your associate just as I had mercy on you?”
18.34: And his lord was angry, and he delivered him to the scourgers until he would pay everything that he owed him.
18.35: So my Father who is in Heaven will do to you unless each of you forgives his brother his offenses from your heart.

19.1: And so it was when Yeshua had finished these sayings, he picked up from Galilee, and he came to the borders of Judea to the other side of the Jordan.
19.2: And great crowds came after him and he healed them there.
19.3: And the Pharisees came to him and they were testing him, and they were saying, “Is it legal for a man to divorce his wife for any cause?”
19.4: But he answered and said to them, “Have you not read that he who made from the beginning, made them male and female?”
19.5: And he said, “Therefore a man shall leave his father and his mother and shall cleave to his wife and the two of them shall be one flesh.”
19.6: “Therefore they were not two, but one flesh. The things therefore that God has united let not a man separate.”
19.7: They were saying to him, “Why therefore did Moses command to give a writing of divorce and to send her away?”
19.8: He said to them, “Moses, confronting the callousness of your heart, let you divorce your wives, but from the beginning it was not so.”
19.9: But I say to you, “Whoever divorces his wife apart from adultery and will take another, commits adultery, and whoever will take her who is divorced commits adultery.”
19.10: His disciples were saying to him, “If the accusations are thus between a man and a wife, it is not expedient to take a wife.”
19.11: But he said to them, “Not every man can receive this saying, except he to whom it is given.”
