19.12: “For there are eunuchs who were born so from their mother's womb and there are eunuchs who became eunuchs by men and there are those who have made themselves eunuchs for the cause of the Kingdom of Heaven. Whoever can receive it let him receive it.”
19.13: And they brought children to him that he might lay his hand upon them and pray, and his disciples rebuked them.
19.14: But Yeshua said to them, “Let the children come to me and do not forbid them, for the Kingdom of Heaven belongs to such as these.”
19.15: And he laid his hand upon them and went on from there.
19.16: And one came near and said to him, “Good teacher, what good thing shall I do that I may have eternal life?”
19.17: But he said to him, “Why do you call me good? There is none good except God alone. But if you want to enter life, keep the commandments.”
19.18: He said to him, “Which ones?” But Yeshua said to him, “You shall not murder, You shall not commit adultery, You shall not steal, You shall not testify falsely.”
19.19: “Honor your father and your mother”, and “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
19.20: That young man said to him, “I have kept all these from my childhood; what am I lacking?”
19.21: Yeshua said to him, “If you want to be perfect, go sell your possessions and give to the poor and you will have treasure in Heaven, and come after me.”
19.22: But that young man heard this saying and he went away, as it was grievous to him, for he had many possessions.
19.23: But Yeshua said to his disciples, “Amen, I say to you, that it is difficult for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of Heaven.”
19.24: “And again I say to you that it is easier for a camel to enter the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God.”
19.25: But the disciples when they heard, they were greatly amazed and they were saying, “Who then can have life?”
19.26: Yeshua gazed at them and he said to them, “This is impossible with the children of men, but everything is possible with God.”
19.27: Then Kaypha answered and said to him, “Behold, we have left everything and we have come after you. What then will happen to us?”
19.28: Yeshua said to them, “Surely, I say to you who have come after me, in The New World when The Son of Man sits on the throne of his glory, you also will sit on twelve thrones and will judge the twelve Tribes of Israel.”
19.29: “And every man who leaves a house or a brother or sister or father or mother or wife or children or towns for my name's sake, each will receive a hundredfold and will inherit eternal life.
19.30: But many are first who will be last and the last ones will be the first.”

20.1: “For the Kingdom of Heaven is like the man, the lord of a household, who went out at dawn to hire laborers for his vineyard.
20.2: And he made an agreement with the laborers for a denarius for the day and he sent them to his vineyard.
20.3: And he went out at the third hour and saw others who were standing in the marketplace and were idle.
20.4: And he said to them, 'You go also to the vineyard; whatever is appropriate I shall give you.'
20.5: But those departed and he went out again at the sixth and at the ninth hours and did likewise.
20.6: And towards the 11th hour he went out and he found others who were standing and were idle, and he said to them, 'Why are you standing and are idle all day?'
20.7: They were saying to him, 'Because no one has hired us.' He said to them, 'You go also to the vineyard, and whatever is appropriate you will receive.'
20.8: But when it was evening, the owner of the vineyard said to his custodian, 'Call the laborers and give them their wages, and start from the last ones up to the first ones.'
20.9: And those of the 11th hour came and they received a denarius each.
20.10: And when the first ones came they had hoped that they would receive more, and they received a denarius each also.
20.11: And when they received it, they complained to the lord of the estate.
20.12: And they were saying, 'These last ones have worked one hour and you have made them equal to us who have borne the burden and the heat of the day.'
20.13: But he answered and said to one of them, 'My friend, I do no evil to you. Did you not agree with me for a denarius?'
20.14: Take yours and go. But I wish to give to this last group even as to you.
20.15: Or is it illegal for me to do whatever I want to do with my own? Is your eye evil because I am good?'
20.16: So the last will be first and the first last, for the called are many and the chosen ones are few.”
20.17: But Yeshua was prepared to go up to Jerusalem and he took aside his twelve disciples privately on the road and he said to them:
20.18: “Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and The Son of Man will be delivered to the Chief Priests and to the Scribes and they will condemn him to death.
20.19: And they will deliver him to Gentiles, and they will mock him, and they will scourge him, and they will crucify him, and the third day he will arise.”
20.20: Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee came near to him, she and her sons, and she worshiped him and she was asking him something.
20.21: But he said to her, “What do you desire?” And she said to him, “Say that these my two sons will sit, one at your right and one at your left, in your Kingdom.”
20.22: Yeshua answered and he said, “You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am prepared to drink or to be baptized in the baptism in which I am to be baptized?” They were saying to him, “We are able.”
20.23: He said to them, “You will drink my cup and you will be baptized in the baptism in which I am baptized, but for you to sit at my right and at my left is not mine to give except to those for whom it is prepared by my Father.”
20.24: But when the ten heard it, they were angry with those two brothers.
20.25: And Yeshua called them and said to them, “You know the rulers of the Gentiles are their lords and their great ones have authority over them.”
20.26: “It will not be so among you, but whoever wants to be great among you, let him be one who waits on you.”
20.27: “And whoever wants to be first among you let him be a servant to you.”
20.28: “Just as The Son of Man came, not to be ministered to, but to minister, and to give himself a ransom in the place of the many.”
20.29: And when Yeshua went out from Jericho, a great crowd was coming after him.
20.30: And, behold, two blind men were sitting on the side of the road and when they heard that Yeshua was passing by, they gave a cry, and they were saying, “Have mercy on us my Lord, son of David.”
20.31: But the crowds were rebuking them that they would be silent, and they raised their voices all the more and they were saying, “Our Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David.”
20.32: And Yeshua stopped and he called them and he said, “What do you want me to do for you?”
20.33: They were saying to him, “Our Lord, that our eyes may be opened.”
20.34: And Yeshua was moved with pity for them and he touched their eyes, and immediately their eyes were opened and they went after him. Matthew

21.1: And then as he approached Jerusalem and came to Bethphage, by the side of the Mount of Olives, Yeshua sent two of his disciples,
21.2: And he said to them, “Go to this village that is opposite you and at once you will find a donkey that is tied and a colt with her; loose them and bring them to me.”
21.3: “And if a man says anything to you, say to him, 'They are needed by Our Lord', and immediately he will send them here.”
21.4: But this that happened was so that the thing that was spoken by the Prophet would be fulfilled which says:
21.5: “Say to the daughter of Zion, 'Behold, your King comes to you meek and riding on a donkey and upon a colt, the foal of a she donkey.'”
21.6: And the disciples went and did just as Yeshua had commanded them.
21.7: And they brought the donkey and the colt and they placed their garments on the colt and Yeshua rode upon it.
21.8: And a multitude of crowds were spreading their clothes on the road and others were cutting down branches from trees and laying them in the road.
21.9: But the crowds which were going before him and coming after him were crying out and they were saying, “Hosanna to The Son of David! Blessed is he who comes in the name of THE LORD JEHOVAH! Hosanna in The Highest!.”
21.10: And when he entered Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred and they were saying, “Who is this?”
21.11: But the crowds were saying, “This is Yeshua the Prophet who is from Nazareth of Galilee.”
21.12: And Yeshua entered The Temple of God and cast out all of those who sold and bought in The Temple and upset the tables of the money changers and the seats of those who sold doves.
21.13: And he said to them, “It is written: 'My house will be called the House of prayer, but you have made it a den of robbers.' “
21.14: And they brought to him in The Temple the blind and the lame, and he healed them.
21.15: But when the Chief Priests and the Pharisees saw the wonders that he did and the children shouting in The Temple and saying, “Hosanna to The Son of David”, it seemed evil to them.
21.16: And they were saying to him, “Have you heard what these are saying?” Yeshua said to them, “Yes. Have you never read, 'From the mouth of children and infants you have composed a song of praise?' “
21.17: And he left them and he went outside the city to Bethany and spent the night there.
21.18: But at dawn when he returned to the city he was hungry.
21.19: And he saw one fig tree by the road and came to it and he found nothing on it except leaves only, and he said to it, “There will be no fruit on you again forever”, and at once that fig tree withered up.
21.20: And the disciples saw and they marveled and they were saying, “How quickly the fig tree withered up!”
21.21: Yeshua answered and said to them, “Amen, I say to you, if you have faith and you will not doubt, you will do not only this of the fig tree but also if you will say to this mountain, 'Be lifted up and fall into the sea', it will be done.”
21.22: “Everything that you will ask in prayer and believe, you will receive.”
21.23: And when Yeshua came to The Temple, the Chief Priests and the Elders of the people approached him as he taught them, and they were saying to him, “By what authority do you do these things and who gave you this authority?”
21.24: Yeshua answered and said to them, “I also shall ask you something and if you will tell me, I shall also tell you by what authority I do these things.”
21.25: “From where was the baptism of Yohannan, from Heaven or was it from men?” But they were counseling among themselves and saying, “If we say, 'From Heaven', he will say to us, 'And why did you not trust him?' “
21.26: “And we are too afraid of the crowds to say, 'From men', for they all hold Yohannan as a Prophet.”
21.27: They answered and they were saying to him, “We do not know.” Yeshua said to them, “Neither am I telling you by which authority I do these things.”
21.28: “But how does it seem to you? A certain man had two sons and he called the first and said to him, 'My son, go work today in the vineyard.'”
21.29: “But he answered and said, 'I don't want to', but afterward he was moved with regret and he went.”
21.30: “Then he came to the other and said to him likewise, but he answered and said, 'I will, my lord', and he did not go.”
21.31: “Which of these two did the will of his father?” They were saying to him, 'The first.' Yeshua said to them, “Amen, I say to you, that Tax Collectors and prostitutes precede you to the Kingdom of God.”
21.32: “For Yohannan came to you in the way of righteousness and you did not trust him, but Tax Collectors and prostitutes trusted him, and even when you saw it, you were not moved with regret afterward to trust him.”
21.33: “Hear another parable: there was a certain man, a landowner, and he had planted a vineyard enclosed by a fence and he had dug a wine press and had built a tower in it, and had given its care to laborers, and he went abroad.”
21.34: “But when the fruit season had arrived, he sent his servants to the laborers so that they would send some of the fruit of the vineyard to him.”
21.35: “And the laborers seized his servants; they beat one and another they stoned and another they killed.”
21.36: “And he sent again more servants than the first time, and they did the same to them.”
21.37: Finally, he sent to them his son as he said, 'Doubtless they will reverence my son.'”
21.38: “But when the laborers saw the son, they said among themselves, 'This is the heir, come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.'”
21.39: “And they seized and led him outside of the vineyard and killed him.”
21.40: “Therefore, when the Lord of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those laborers?”
21.41: They said to him, “He will ruthlessly destroy them and he will give the care of the vineyard to other laborers, who will give him the fruits in their season.”
21.42: Yeshua said to them, “Have you never read in the scriptures, 'The stone which the builders rejected has become the head of the corner; this was from the presence of THE LORD JEHOVAH, and it is a wonder in our eyes?”
21.43: “Therefore, I say to you, the Kingdom of God will be taken from you and will be given to a people who will produce fruit.”
21.44: “And whoever falls on this stone will be shattered, and it will pulverize to dust everyone upon whom it will fall.”
21.45: And when the Chief Priests and the Pharisees heard his parables, they knew that he had spoken against them.
21.46: And they sought to seize him and they were afraid of the crowds, because they were holding him as a Prophet.

22.1: Again, Yeshua answered in a parable, and he said:
22.2: “The Kingdom of Heaven is compared to a man who was a King who made a wedding feast for his son.
22.3: And he sent his servants to call those invited to the wedding feast, and they chose not to come.
22.4: Again he sent other servants, and he said, “Tell those invited, 'Behold, my banquet is ready, and my oxen and my fatlings are killed, everything is prepared; come to the wedding feast.' “
22.5: And they showed contempt and went, one to his field, and another to his commerce.
22.6: But the rest seized, abused and killed his servants.
22.7: But when the King heard, he was angry and he sent his armies, destroyed those murderers, and burned their city.
22.8: Then he said to his servants, 'The wedding feast is ready, and those who were invited were not worthy.'
22.9: 'Go therefore to the ends of the roads and call everyone whom you find to the wedding feast.'
22.10: And those servants went out to the roads, and they gathered everyone whom they found, bad and good, and the place of the wedding feast was filled with guests.
22.11: And the King entered to see the guests and he saw a man there who was not wearing a wedding garment.
22.12: And he said to him, 'My friend, how did you enter here when you did not have a wedding garment?'
22.13: Then the King said to the attendants, 'Bind his hands and his feet and cast him out into outer darkness; there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.'
22.14: “For the called are many and the chosen are few.”
22.15: And the Pharisees went, and they took counsel how they might catch him in discourse.
22.16: And they sent their disciples to him with those of the house of Herodus and they were saying to him, “Teacher, we know that you are true and that you teach the way of God in truth and you do not take caution for man, for you do not accept the persons of men.”
22.17: “Tell us therefore, how does it seem to you? Is it lawful to give the head tax to Caesar or not?”
22.18: Yeshua knew their evil and he said, “Why are you testing me, you accepters of persons?”
22.19: “Show me a denarius of the head tax money”, and they brought a denarius to him.
22.20: And Yeshua said to them, “Whose is this image and inscription?”
22.21: And they were saying, “Caesar's”; he said to them, “Give therefore what is Caesar's to Caesar, and what is God's to God.”
22.22: And when they heard, they were amazed, and they left him and departed.
22.23: That day the Sadducees approached, and they were saying to him, “There is no life for the dead”, and they asked him,
22.24: And they were saying to him, “Teacher, Moses said to us that if a man dies while he has no sons, his brother may take his wife and raise up seed to his brother.
22.25: Now, there were seven brothers with us; the first took a wife and he died, and he had no children, and he left his wife to his brother.
22.26: Likewise also the second and also the third, even unto the seventh of them.
22.27: And after all of them the woman died also.
22.28: In the resurrection therefore, which of these seven will have the woman, for they all had taken her?”
22.29: Yeshua answered and he said to them, “You do err, because you do not understand the scriptures, neither the mighty works of God.
22.30: For in the resurrection of the dead, they do not take wives, neither do men have wives, but they are like the Angels of God in Heaven.
22.31: But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken to you by God, who said:
22.32: 'I AM THE LIVING GOD, The God of Abraham, The God of Isaaq, and The God of Jaqob?' He is The God, not of the dead, but of the living.”
22.33: And when the crowds heard, they were dumbfounded at his teaching.
22.34: But when the Pharisees heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, they assembled together.
22.35: And one of them who knew The Written Law asked him while testing him:
22.36: “Teacher, which commandment in The Written Law is the greatest?”
22.37: Yeshua said to him, “You shall love THE LORD JEHOVAH your God from all your heart and from all your soul and from all your power and from all your mind.”
22.38: “This is the great and the first commandment.”
22.39: “And the second which is like it is, 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.'
22.40: On these two commands depend all The Written Law and The Prophets.”
22.41: But as the Pharisees were assembled, Yeshua asked them,
22.42: And he said, “What are you saying about The Messiah? Whose Son is He?” They were saying to him, “The Son of David.”
22.43: He said to them, “And how did David by The Spirit call him THE LORD JEHOVAH, for he said:”
22.44: 'THE LORD JEHOVAH said to my Lord, 'sit at my right hand until I place your enemies under your feet'?
22.45: “If therefore David called him THE LORD JEHOVAH, how is he his son?”
22.46: And no man could give him an answer, and no man dared again from that day to question him.

23.1: Then Yeshua spoke with the crowds and with his disciples:
23.2: And he said to them:”The Scribes and the Pharisees have sat on the throne of Moses.”
23.3: Everything therefore that they will tell you to observe, observe and do, but you should not do according to their works, for they are saying, and they are not doing.
23.4: And they bind heavy burdens and place them on the shoulders of men, but they are not willing to touch them with their fingers.
23.5: And they do all their works to be seen by the children of men, for they enlarge their phylacteries and they extend the blue fringes of their robes.
23.6: And they love the first class places at feasts and first class seats in the synagogues
23.7: And greetings in the marketplaces, and to be called, “Rabbi”, by the people.
23.8: But you shall not be called “Rabbi”, for One is your Rabbi, but you are all brothers.
23.9: And you should not call yourselves “Father”, in the earth, for one is your Father who is in Heaven.
23.10: And you will not be called Leaders, because one is your Leader, The Messiah.
23.11: But he who is great among you will be a servant to you.
23.12: Whoever will exalt himself will be humbled and whoever will humble himself will be exalted.
23.13: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, pretenders, who consume the houses of widows with offerings for your making of long prayers! Because of this you will receive greater judgment.
23.14: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, pretenders, for you shut the Kingdom of Heaven before the children of men, for you are not entering, and those who are entering you do not permit to enter!
23.15: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, phonies! For you travel around sea and land to make one convert, and when it has happened, you make him doubly the son of Gehenna that you are!
23.16: Woe to you blind guides, for you say, 'Whoever swears by The Temple, it is nothing', but 'Whoever swears by the gold of The Temple is liable!'
23.17: Fools and blind men! Which is greater, gold, or The Temple, which sanctifies the gold?
23.18: And,'Whoever swears by the altar, it is nothing',but 'Whoever swears by the offering upon it, he is liable.'
23.19: Fools and blind men! Which is greater, the gift or the altar that sanctifies the gift?
23.20: Whoever swears therefore by the altar swears by it and by everything that is upon it.
23.21: And whoever swears by The Temple swears by it and by The One dwelling in it.
23.22: And whoever swears by Heaven swears by the throne of God and by him who sits upon it.
23.23: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, imposters! For you tithe mint and dill and cummin and you forsake the weighty things of the law: Justice, mercy and faith! It is necessary for you to do these things and you should not forsake them.
23.24: Blind guides who strain out gnats and swallow camels!
23.25: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, pretenders, who wash the outside of the cup and of the dish, but within are full of plunder and evil!
23.26: Blind Pharisees, wash first the inside of the cup and dish that their outside may also be clean.
23.27: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, pretenders, who are like white tombs, which from the outside appear lovely, but from within are full of the bones of the dead and all corruption!
23.28: So also you from the outside appear to the children of men as righteous, and from within are filled with evil and hypocrisy.
23.29: Woe to you Scribes and Pharisees, phonies, who build the tombs of The Prophets and adorn the tombs of the righteous!
23.30: And you say, 'If we had been in the days of our forefathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of The Prophets.'
23.31: Therefore you testify against yourselves that you are the children of those who murdered The Prophets.
23.32: So fulfill the standard of your forefathers.
23.33: Snakes! Offspring of vipers! How will you escape from the judgment of Gehenna?
23.34: Because of this behold, I am sending to you Prophets and wise men and scribes; some of them you will murder and you will crucify, and some of them you will scourge in your synagogues and you will persecute them from city to city
23.35: So that all the blood of the righteous may come upon you that has been shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel, even unto the blood of Zechariah the son of Barachiah, whom you murdered in the midst of The Temple and the altar.
23.36: Amen, I say to you, all these things will come upon this generation.
23.37: Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you that murdered The Prophets and stoned those who were sent to it! How many times have I desired to gather your children, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were not willing!
23.38: Behold, your house is left to you desolate!
23.39: For I say to you that you will not see me from now on, until you will say, 'Blessed is he who has come in the name of THE LORD JEHOVAH.'”

24.1: Yeshua went out from The Temple to depart, and his disciples approached, showing him the buildings of The Temple.
24.2: But he said to them, “Behold, do you see all these things? Amen, I say to you that not a stone will be left here standing, which will not be pulled down.”
24.3: And when Yeshua sat onTur d'Zaytay, his disciples came and they were saying among themselves and to him: “Tell us when these things will be and what will be the sign of your advent and of the end of the world.”
24.4: Yeshua answered and said to them, “Beware that no man will deceive you.”
24.5: “For many will come in my name, and they will say. 'I AM THE LIVING GOD, The Messiah', and they will deceive many.”
24.6: It is going to happen that you are going to hear battles and reports of wars.Take heed that you will not be troubled, for it is necessary that all these things should happen, but it will not yet be the end.
24.7: For nation will arise against nation, and Kingdom against Kingdom, and there will be famines and plagues and earthquakes in various places.
24.8: But all these things are the beginning of sorrows.
24.9: And then they will deliver you to suffering, and they will kill you and you will be hated by all the nations because of my name.
24.10: Then many will be subverted, and they will hate one another and will betray one another.
24.11: And many false Prophets will arise and will deceive many.
24.12: And because of the abundance of evil, the love of many will grow cold.
24.13: But whoever will persevere until the end will have life.
24.14: And this gospel of the Kingdom will be preached in the whole world for the testimony of all the nations and then the end will come.
24.15: But whenever you will see the desecrated sign of desolation that was spoken by Daniel the Prophet, standing in the holy place, ( he who reads should consider )
24.16: Then those who are in Judea should flee to the mountains.
24.17: And the one who is on the roof should not come down to take what is in his house.
24.18: And he who is in the field should not return to take his clothes.
24.19: But woe to pregnant women and to those who are nursing in those days.
24.20: But pray that your escape will not be in winter, neither on the Sabbath.
24.21: For then there will be great suffering, which has not been from the beginning of the world even until now, neither will be.
24.22: If those days are not cut short no one would live, but because of the chosen ones, those days will be cut short.
24.23: Then if someone will say to you, “Behold, The Messiah is here or there”, you should not believe.
24.24: For false Messiahs will arise and Prophets of lies, and they will give great signs so as to deceive, if possible, even the elect.
24.25: Behold, I have told you beforehand.
24.26: If therefore they will say to you, “Behold, he is in the desert”, you should not go out, or “Behold, he is in an inner room”, do not believe it.
24.27: For just as lightning goes out from The East and appears unto The West, so will the coming of The Son of Man be.
24.28: Wherever the body will be, there will the eagles be gathered.
24.29: But immediately after the suffering of those days, the sun will darken and the moon will not show its light, and the stars will fall from the heavens and the power of the heavens will be disturbed.
24.30: And then the sign of The Son of Man in Heaven will appear and then all the families of the earth will mourn, and they will see The Son of Man who comes on the clouds of Heaven with miracles and many praises.
24.31: And he will send his Angels with great trumpets, and they will gather his own elect from the four winds, from all the ends of the heavens.
24.32: But learn a parable from the fig tree: As soon as its branches bow low and its leaves bud forth, you know that summer has arrived.
24.33: So also, whenever you see all these things, know that he has approached the door.
24.34: Amen, I say to you that this generation will not pass away until all these things happen.
24.35: Heaven and Earth will pass away, and my words will not pass away.
24.36: But about that day and about that hour no one knows, not even the Angels of Heaven, but The Father alone.
24.37: But just as the days of Noah, so will the coming of The Son of Man be.
24.38: For just as they were eating and drinking before the flood, and they were taking wives, and they were taking husbands, until the day that Noah entered the ark,
24.39: And they did not perceive until the flood came and took them all away, thus will be the coming of The Son of Man.
24.40: Then two will be in the field; one will be taken captive, and one will be left.
24.41: Two women will be grinding at the mill; one will be taken captive and one will be left.
24.42: Wake up therefore, for you do not know in what hour your Lord will come.
24.43: But know this: if the house owner had known in what watch the robber would come, he would have been awake and would not have allowed his house to be broken into.
24.44: Because of this, be also ready, because at the hour in which you are not expecting, The Son of Man will come.
24.45: Who then is the servant who is faithful and wise, whom his Lord has appointed over the children of his household, to give them food in his time?
24.46: Blessed is that servant, whom, when his master will come, will find doing this.
24.47: Amen, I say to you, he will set him over everything that he has.
24.48: But if an evil servant will say in his heart, “My Lord delays to come”,
24.49: And will start to beat his associates and eat and drink with drunkards,
24.50: The Lord of that servant will come on the day that he does not expect it, and in the hour in which he is not aware.
24.51: And he will cut him off, and he will set his portion with the phonies. There will be weeping and gnashing teeth.”

25.1: “Then the Kingdom of Heaven will be compared to ten virgins; the same took their lamps and went to meet the groom and the bride.
25.2: But five of them were wise and five were foolish.
25.3: And those fools took their lamps, and did not take oil with them.
25.4: But those wise ones took oil in their vessels with their lamps.
25.5: But when the groom delayed, all of them grew tired and slept.
25.6: And in the middle of the night there was an outcry, “Behold, The groom has come, go out to meet him.”
25.7: Then all those virgins arose and trimmed their lamps.
25.8: The fools said to the wise, “Give us some of your oil, behold, our lamps have gone out.”
25.9: But the wise answered and said, “Why? There is not enough for us and for you; go to those who sell and buy for yourselves.”
25.10: And when they went to buy, the groom came and those who were ready entered with him into the wedding place, and the door was barred.
25.11: But afterward, those other virgins came and they were saying, “Our Lord, Our Lord, open to us.”
25.12: But he answered and said to them, 'Amen, I say to you, that I do not know you.'
25.13: Wake up therefore, for you know neither the day nor the hour.
25.14: Like the man who journeyed and called his servants and delivered to them his property.
25.15: To one he gave five talents, and to another two, and to another one, each man according to his power, and he immediately went abroad.
25.16: But he who received five talents went and traded them and gained five others.
25.17: So also he of the two gained two others.
25.18: But he who received one went and dug in the ground and buried the money of his lord.
25.19: After much time, the lord of the servants came and took an account of them.
25.20: And he called him who had received five talents and brought five others, and he said, “My lord, you gave me five talents behold, I have gained five other talents on top of them.”
25.21: His master said to him, ''Well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over a little; I shall set you over much; enter the joy of your Lord.'
25.22: And he of his two talents came and he said, “My lord, you gave me two talents, behold, I have gained two other talents on top of them.”
25.23: His lord said to him, “Well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over a little; I shall set you over much; enter the joy of your Lord.”
25.24: He also who had received one talent came, and he said, “My lord, I had known you that you are a hard man, and that you reap where you have not sown and that you gather from where you have not threshed,
25.25: And I was afraid, and I went and buried your talent in the ground. Behold, it is yours.”
25.26: His master answered and said to him, “You evil and lazy servant; you knew that I reaped where I had not sown, and I gathered from where I have not threshed.
25.27: And it was incumbent upon you to cast my money to the exchange, so that when I would come, I could require my own with its interest.
25.28: Take therefore the talent from him and give it to him who has ten talents.”
25.29: For to the one who has it, it shall be given, and it will be increased to him. But whoever does not have it, that which he has will be taken from him.
25.30: And they cast the worthless servant into outer darkness. There will be weeping and gnashing teeth.
25.31: But whenever The Son of Man comes in his glory and all his Holy Angels with him, then he will sit upon the throne of his glory.
25.32: And all the nations will be assembled before him and he will separate them one from another, as a shepherd who separates sheep from goats.
25.33: And he will place the sheep at his right and the goats at his left.
25.34: Then The King will say to those who are at his right, 'Come, blessed ones of my Father, inherit the Kingdom that was prepared for you from the foundation of the universe.'
25.35: For I was hungry and you gave me food, and I was thirsty and you gave me drink. I was a stranger and you took me in.
25.36: I was naked and you clothed me. I was sick, and you took care of me. I was in prison, and you came to me.'
25.37: Then the righteous will say to him, 'Our Lord, When did we see you that you were hungry and we fed you, or that you were thirsty and we gave you drink?
25.38: And when did we see you, that you were a stranger and we took you in, or that you were naked and we clothed you?'
25.39: 'And when did we see you sick or in a prison, and we came to you?'
25.40: And The King answers and says to them, 'Amen, I say to you, as much as you have done to one of these my little brothers, you have done that to me.'
25.41: Then he will say also to those who are at his left, 'Depart from me, you cursed ones, into eternal fire, that which was prepared for The Devil and for his Angels.
25.42: For I was hungry and you gave me no food. I was thirsty and you gave me no drink.
25.43: I was a stranger and you did not take me in; I was naked, and you did not clothe me. I was sick, and in prison and you did not take care of me.'
25.44: And those will answer, and they will say, 'Our Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and we did not minister to you?'
25.45: Then he will answer and he will say to them, 'Amen, I say to you, as much as you have not done to one of these little ones, neither have you done that to me.'
25.46: And these will go into eternal torture, and the righteous into eternal life.”

26.1: And it was, that when Yeshua had finished all these words, he said to his disciples:
26.2: “You know that after two days it is Passover and The Son of Man will be betrayed to be crucified.
26.3: Then the Chief Priests and the Scribes and the Elders of the people were gathered together to the court of The High Priest, who is called Qaiapha,
26.4: And they held a council about Yeshua, so that they might seize him by deceit and murder him.
26.5: And they were saying, “Not during the feast lest there be a riot among the people.”
26.6: And when Yeshua was in Bethany in the House of Shimeon the Potter,
26.7: A woman came near to him who had with her of vase of oil of sweet spices, very expensive, and she poured it on Yeshua's head as he reclined.
26.8: But his disciples saw it and it displeased them and they said, “Why this waste?”
26.9: “For it would have been possible to sell this for much and it might have been given to the poor.”
26.10: But Yeshua knew and he said to them, “Why do you trouble the woman? She has done a beautiful deed for me.
26.11: For you have the poor always with you, but you do not have me always.
26.12: But she who has poured this ointment on my body has done it as for my burial.
26.13: And amen, I say to you, that wherever this my gospel will be preached in all the world, this also that she has done will be told for her memorial.”
26.14: Then one of the twelve who is called Yehuda Scariota went out to the Chief Priests,
26.15: And he said to them, ''What are you willing to give me if I shall deliver him to you?', but they promised him thirty silver coins.
26.16: And from then on, he sought opportunity to betray him.
26.17: But on the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Yeshua and they said to him, “Where do you want us to prepare for you that you may eat the Passover?”
26.18: But he said to them, “Go to the city to a certain man and say to him, 'Our Rabbi says, 'My time is come. I will perform the Passover at your place with my disciples'.”
26.19: And his disciples did just as Yeshua ordered them and they prepared the Passover.
26.20: And when it was evening he reclined with his twelve Disciples.
26.21: And as they ate he said to them, “Amen, I say to you, that one of you will betray me.”
26.22: And it grieved them greatly, and they began to say to him, each one of them, “Is it I, my Lord?”
26.23: But he answered and said, “Whoever dips his hand with me in the dish, he will betray me.”
26.24: “And The Son of Man goes just as it is written about him, but woe to that man by whom The Son of Man is betrayed; it would have been better for that man if he had not been born.”
26.25: Yehuda the traitor answered and he said, “It is I, Rabbi?” Yeshua said to him, “You have said.”
26.26: But as they ate, Yeshua took bread and blessed and broke and he gave to his disciples, and he said, “Take eat; this is my body.”
26.27: And he took a cup, and he gave thanks and he gave to them, and he said, “Take, drink from it, all of you.
26.28: This is my blood of the new covenant, which is shed in exchange for the many for the release of sins.
26.29: But I say to you that I shall not drink again from this fruit of the vine until the day in which I shall drink it with you new in the Kingdom of my Father.”
26.30: And they sang praises and they went out toTur Zaytay.
26.31: And Yeshua said to them, “All of you will be offended at me this night, for it is written: 'I shall strike The Shepherd, and the sheep of his flock will be scattered.'
26.32: But after I am risen, I shall go before you to Galilee.”
26.33: Kaypha answered and said to him, “Even if every man will be offended at you, I will never be offended at you.”
26.34: Yeshua answered him and said, “Amen, I say to you that in this night, before a cock will crow three times, you will deny me.”
26.35: Kaypha said to him, “If I should die with you, I would not deny you.” So also all the disciples said.
26.36: Then Yeshua came with them to the place that is called Gethsemane and he said to his disciples, “Sit here while I shall go and pray.”
26.37: And he took Kaypha and the two sons of Zebedee, and he began to be saddened and to be disheartened.
26.38: And he said to them, “My soul has sorrow even to death; wait for me here and keep watch with me.”
26.39: And he withdrew a little and he fell upon his face and he prayed and he said, “My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass by me, however not as I will, but as you will.”
26.40: And he came to his disciples and he found them as they slept and he said to Kaypha, “Could you not keep watch with me one hour?”
26.41: “Watch and pray lest you enter into temptation. The Spirit is ready, but the body is weak.”
26.42: Going again the second time, he prayed and he said, “My Father, if this cup cannot pass unless I drink it, your will be done.”
26.43: And coming again, he found them while they slept, for their eyes were heavy.
26.44: And he left them and going on again, he prayed the third time, and he said the same thing.
26.45: And he came to his disciples and he said to them, “Sleep now and rest; behold the hour is come; The Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.”
26.46: “Arise, let us go; he has arrived who betrays me.”
26.47: While he was speaking, behold, Yehuda the traitor, one of the twelve, came and a great crowd with him, with swords and clubs from the presence of the Chief Priests and the Elders of the people.
26.48: And Yehuda the traitor had given them a sign, and he had said, “Him whom I shall kiss is the one; seize him.”
26.49: And at once, he called Yeshua, and he said, “Shalom, Rabbi”, and he kissed him.
26.50: Then Yeshua said to him, “Have you come to this my friend?” Then they came and they laid their hands on Yeshua, and they took him.
26.51: And behold, one of those who were with Yeshua reached his hand and drew his sword and struck the servant of The High Priest and cut off his ear.
26.52: Then Yeshua said to him, “Return the sword to its place, for all of those who take up swords will die by swords.
26.53: Do you think that I cannot ask my Father and he would raise up for me now more than twelve Legions of Angels?
26.54: How then would the Scriptures be fulfilled, that it must be so?”
26.55: At that moment Yeshua said to the crowd, “Have you come out as against a robber with swords and with clubs to seize me? I was with you every day in The Temple sitting and teaching, and you did not arrest me.”
26.56: But this happened that the scripture of The Prophets may be fulfilled; then all the disciples forsook him and fled.
26.57: And they who arrested Yeshua led him to Qaiapha the High Priest, where the Scribes and the Elders were gathered.
26.58: But Shimeon Kaypha was going after him from a distance unto the court of The High Priest, and entering he sat down inside with the guards to see the outcome.
26.59: But the Chief Priests and the Elders and all the assembly were seeking witnesses against Yeshua, so that they might put him to death.
26.60: And they did not find them, though many false witnesses had come, but finally two came forth,
26.61: And they were saying: “This one said, 'I can destroy The Temple of God and in three days I shall build it.'”
26.62: And the High Priest stood and said to him, “Do you not return an answer? What are these testifying against you?”
26.63: But Yeshua was silent, and The High Priest answered and said to him, “I adjure you by THE LIVING GOD that you tell us if you are The Messiah, The Son of God.”
26.64: Yeshua said to him, “You have said; but I say to you that from this hour, you will see The Son of Man who sits at the right hand of power and comes on the clouds of Heaven.”
26.65: Then the High Priest ripped his garment, and said, “Behold, he has blasphemed. Why now do we need witnesses? Behold now, you have heard his blasphemy.
26.66: “What do you think?” They answered, and they said, “He deserves death.”
26.67: And they spat in his face, and they were beating his head. But others were striking him
26.68: And were saying, “Prophesy to us, Messiah; who is it that hits you?”
26.69: But Kaypha had sat outside in the courtyard, and a maid servant came near him, and she said to him, “You also were with Yeshua the Nazarene.”
26.70: But he denied before all of them and he said, “I do not know what you are saying.”
26.71: And when he went out to the porch, another Maidservant saw him and she said to them who were there, “This one also was there with Yeshua the Nazarene.”
26.72: And again he denied with an oath, “I do not know the man.”
26.73: After a bit, those standing there came and they said to Kaypha, “Certainly, you also are one of them, for your speech reveals you.”
26.74: And he began to curse and to swear, “I do not know the man”, and at that moment, a cock crowed.
26.75: And Kaypha remembered the word of Yeshua that he had told him, “Before a cock will crow three times, you will deny me”; and going forth outside, he wept bitterly.

27.1: But when it was dawn, all the Chief Priests and the Elders of the people took counsel against Yeshua, how they would put him to death.
27.2: And they bound him and they led him and delivered him to Pilate, the Governor.
27.3: Then when Yehuda the traitor saw that Yeshua was condemned, he was moved with regret and went and brought those thirty pieces of silver to the Chief Priests and to the Elders.
27.4: And he said, “I have sinned, for I have betrayed innocent blood”, but they said to him, “What is that to us? You know us.”
27.5: And he cast the silver into The Temple and departed, and he went and hanged himself.
27.6: But the Chief Priests took the silver, and they said, “It is not legal to put it into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.”
27.7: And they took counsel, and they bought with it the field of a potter as a graveyard for the burial of strangers.
27.8: Therefore that field has been called, “The Field of Blood”, until this day.
27.9: Then was fulfilled what was spoken by the Prophet who said, “I took thirty silver coins, the price of The Precious One on which they of the children of Israel had agreed.
27.10: And I gave them for the potter's field as THE LORD JEHOVAH commanded me.”
27.11: But Yeshua himself stood before the Governor and the Governor asked him and said to him, “You are The King of the Judeans?”, and Yeshua said to him, “You have said.”
27.12: And when the Chief Priests and the Elders accused him, he did not return any answer.
27.13: Then Pilate said to him, “Have you not heard how much they testify against you?”
27.14: And he gave him no response, not even a word, and at this he marveled greatly.
27.15: Now, at every feast, the Governor was accustomed to release one prisoner to the people, whomever they had chosen.
27.16: But one of their prisoners was a notable prisoner called Barabba.
27.17: And when they had been assembled, Pilate said to them, “Whom do you wish that I should release to you, Barabba, or Yeshua who is called The Messiah?”
27.18: For Pilate knew that for jealousy they had delivered him.
27.19: But when the Governor sat on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him and she said, “Have nothing to do with that Righteous One, for I have suffered greatly in my dream today because of him.”
27.20: But the Chief Priests and the Elders had persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabba, but to destroy Yeshua.
27.21: And the Governor answered and said to them, “Whom do you want me to release to you of the two?” But they said, “Barabba.”
27.22: Pilate said to them, “And Yeshua, who is called The Messiah, what shall I do to him?” And all of them were saying, “Let him be crucified.”
27.23: The Governor said to them, “What evil has he done”, but increasingly, they cried out and they said, “Let him be crucified!.”
27.24: And when Pilate saw that nothing availed, but that there was an increasing clamor, he took water, washing his hands before the crowds and he said, “I am free from the blood of this righteous man. Know that.”
27.25: And all the people answered, and they said, “His blood be upon us and upon our children.”
27.26: Then he released Barabba to them and scourged Yeshua with whips and delivered him to be crucified.
27.27: Then the soldiers of the Governor led Yeshua to the Praetorium, and they gathered the whole regiment around him.
27.28: And they stripped him and they clothed him with a scarlet robe.
27.29: And they wound a garland of thorns and placed it on his head and a reed in his right hand and they bowed on their knees before him and were mocking him and saying, “Hail, King of the Judeans!”
27.30: And they spat in his face and they took the reed and they were hitting him on his head.
27.31: And when they had mocked him, they stripped him of the robe and clothed him in his garments and led him to be crucified.
27.32: And as they went out, they found a Cyrenian man whose name was Shimeon; they compelled him to carry his cross.
27.33: And they came to the place that was called “Gagultha”, which is interpreted, “a Skull”.
27.34: And they gave him vinegar to drink that was mixed with gall, and he tasted and he did not want to drink it.
27.35: And when they had crucified him, they divided his garments by lots.
27.36: And they were sitting and keeping watch for him there.
27.37: And they placed over his head the cause of his death in writing: “This is Yeshua the King of the Judeans.”
27.38: And two robbers were crucified with him, one at his right hand and one at his left.
27.39: But those who were passing by were reviling him and shaking their heads;
27.40: And they were saying, “The One who destroys The Temple and builds it in three days, save yourself, if you are The Son of God, and come down from the cross.”
27.41: Thus also the Chief Priests were mocking with the Scribes and the Elders and the Pharisees.
27.42: And they were saying, “He saved others, he cannot save himself; if he is The King of Israel, let him descend now from the cross and we will trust in him.”
27.43: “He trusted on God, let him save him now, if he delights in him, for he has said, 'I am The Son of God.' “
27.44: Thus also those robbers who were crucified with him were taunting him.
27.45: But from the sixth hour there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour.
27.46: And toward the ninth hour Yeshua cried with a loud voice and he said, “Oh God, oh God! Why have you forsaken me?”
27.47: Those people who were standing there, when they had heard, they were saying, “This one has called Elijah.”
27.48: At that moment one of them ran and took a sponge and filled it with vinegar and placed it on a reed and gave a drink to him.
27.49: But the rest were saying, “Let him alone; we shall see if Elijah comes to save him.”
27.50: But Yeshua cried again with a loud voice, and his Spirit departed.
27.51: And at once the curtain entrance of The Temple was ripped in two from top to bottom. The earth was shaken and the rocks were split.
27.52: Tombs were opened, and many bodies of the Saints who were sleeping arose.
27.53: And they came out, and after his resurrection, they entered the Holy City, and they appeared to many.
27.54: And the Centurion and those who were guarding Yeshua, when they saw the quake and those things that happened, they were very afraid, and they said, “Truly, this was The Son of God.”
27.55: But there were also many women there who had seen from a distance, these who had come after Yeshua from Galilee and had ministered to him.
27.56: One of them was Maryam Magdalitha and Maryam the mother of Yaqob and of Yose and the mother of those sons of Zebedee.
27.57: When it was evening, a rich man from Ramtha named Yoseph came, who also had been a disciple of Yeshua,
27.58: This one came to Pilate and requested the body of Yeshua, and Pilate commanded that the body would be given to him.
27.59: And Yoseph took the body and wound it in a sheet of pure linen.
27.60: And he placed it in a new tomb belonging to him, which was cut in stone, and they rolled a great stone and set it against the doorway of the tomb and they departed.
27.61: But Maryam Magdalitha and the other Maryam were there, sitting opposite the tomb.
27.62: And the next day, which is after Friday sunset, the Chief Priests and the Pharisees were gathered together unto Pilate,
27.63: And they were saying to him, “Our Lord, we recall that the deceiver said while he was alive, 'After three days, I will arise.' “
27.64: “Command therefore to guard the tomb until the third day, lest his disciples should come and steal it in the night and say to the people that he is risen from the grave, and the last deception be worse than the first.”
27.65: Pilate said to them, “You have guards, go guard it just as you know how.”
27.66: But they went to guard the tomb, and they together with the guards sealed the stone.

28.1: But on the eve of the Sabbath, when the first of the week was dawning, Maryam Magdalitha and the other Maryam came to see the tomb.
28.2: And behold there was a great earthquake, for The Angel of THE LORD JEHOVAH descended from Heaven, and he came, he rolled the stone from the entrance and sat upon it.
28.3: And his appearance was like lightning and his clothing was white as snow.
28.4: And from dread of him, those who were keeping watch were shaken, and they became like dead men.
28.5: But the Angel answered and said to the women, “Do not be afraid, for I know that you are seeking Yeshua, who was crucified.”
28.6: “He is not here, for he is raised just as he said; come see the place in which our Lord was laid.”
28.7: “And go quickly; say to his disciples that he has risen from the grave, and behold, he goes before you to Galilee; there you will see him; behold I have told you.”
28.8: And they went quickly from the tomb with fear and with great joy, and they ran to tell his disciples.
28.9: And behold, Yeshua met them and he said to them, “Peace to you”, but they came and held his feet and they worshiped him.
28.10: Then Yeshua said to them, “Do not be afraid, but go tell my brothers to go to Galilee and there they will see me.”
28.11: And as they were going, some of the guards came to the city and they told the Chief Priests everything that had occurred.
28.12: And they gave not a few silver shekels to the guards and they gathered with the Elders and held a council.
28.13: And they were saying to them, “Say, 'His disciples came and stole it in the night, while we slept'.”
28.14: “And if this should be reported before the Governor, we will persuade him, and we will relieve your concerns.”
28.15: But when they took the silver coins, they did as they had instructed them, and this story has gone out among the Judeans till this day.
28.16: But the eleven disciples went to Galilee to the mountain where Yeshua had appointed them.
28.17: And when they saw him they worshiped him, but some of them doubted.
28.18: And Yeshua spoke with them and he said to them, “All authority has been given to me in Heaven and in the earth; in the manner in which my Father has sent me, I am sending you.”
28.19: “Therefore go disciple all the nations and baptize them in the name of The Father and The Son and The Spirit of Holiness.”
28.20: “And instruct them to keep everything whatever I have commanded you, and behold, I am with you every day, even unto the end of time. Amen”

1.1: The beginning of The Gospel of Yeshua The Messiah, The Son of God.
1.2: As it is written in Isaiah the Prophet, “Behold, I shall send my messenger before your presence to prepare your way.”
1.3: “A voice that cries in the wilderness, prepare the way of THE LORD JEHOVAH and make level his paths.”
1.4: Yohannan was in the wilderness, baptizing and preaching the baptism of repentance for the release of sins.
1.5: And all the country of Judea and all the people of Jerusalem were going out to him, and he baptized them in the Jordan when they confessed their sins.
1.6: But the same Yohannan was clothed with clothing of hair of the camel and he was bound with a belt of leather at his waist and his food was locusts and honey of the field.
1.7: And he was preaching and he said, “Behold, after me shall come he who is mightier than I, the strap of whose sandals I am not worthy to stoop and to loose.
1.8: I have immersed you in water, but he will immerse you in The Spirit of Holiness.
1.9: And it was in those days; Yeshua came from Nazareth of Galilee and was immersed in the Jordan by Yohannan.
1.10: And at once, as he came up from the waters, he saw the heavens being ripped open and The Spirit who was descending upon him as a dove.
1.11: And there was a voice from the heavens: “You are my Son, The Beloved; with you I am delighted.”
1.12: And at once The Spirit drove him into the wilderness.
1.13: And he had been there in the wilderness forty days when he was tempted by Satan. And he was with the animals, and Angels were ministering to him.
1.14: After Yohannan was delivered up, Yeshua came to Galilee and was preaching The Gospel of the Kingdom of God.
1.15: And he said, “Time is coming to an end. The Kingdom of God has arrived. Repent and believe in The Good News.”
1.16: And as he walked around the Sea of Galilee, he saw Shimeon and his brother Andraeus who were casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
1.17: And Yeshua said to them, “Come after me, and I will make you fishers of men.”
1.18: And at once they left their nets and went after him.
1.19: And when he passed by a little he saw Yaqob, son of Zebedee, and Yohannan his brother, and also those in the ship who were setting their nets in order.
1.20: And he called them and at once they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired servants and they went after him.
1.21: And when they entered Kapernahum, at once he taught in their synagogue on the Sabbath.
1.22: And they were dumbfounded at his teaching, for he was teaching them as one having authority and not like their Scribes.
1.23: And in their synagogue there was a man who had a vile spirit in him, and he cried out
1.24: And he said, “What business do we have with you, Yeshua the Nazarene? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are, The Holy One of God.”
1.25: And Yeshua rebuked him and said, “Shut your mouth and come out of him.”
1.26: And the foul spirit threw him down and he cried out in a loud voice and came out of him.
1.27: And all of them marveled and they were inquiring with one another, saying, “What is this?”, and “What is this new teaching? For he commands even the foul spirits with authority and they obey him.”
1.28: And at once his fame went out in the whole region of Galilee.
1.29: And they went out from the synagogue and they came to the house of Shimeon and Andraeus with Yaqob and Yohannan.
1.30: And the Mother-in-law of Shimeon was lying ill with fever and they told him about her.
1.31: And he came near and took her by the hand and raised her up and at once her fever left her and she was waiting on them.
1.32: But in the evening at the going down of the sun they brought to him all of them who had been ill and demon possessed.
1.33: And the whole city was assembled at the door.
1.34: And he healed multitudes that had become ill with various diseases and he cast out many evil spirits. He did not allow them to speak because they did know him.
1.35: And in the very early morning he arose first and went on to a desolate place and there he prayed.
1.36: And Shimeon and his companions were seeking for him.
1.37: And when they found him they were all saying to him, “The people are all looking for you.”
1.38: He said to them, “Walk to the villages and the cities near to us, so that I also may preach there, for because of this I have come.”
1.39: And he was preaching in all their synagogues and in all Galilee and he cast out demons.
1.40: A leper came to him, fell at his feet, and begged him, saying, “If you are willing, you are able to make me clean.”
1.41: Yeshua was moved with compassion for him. reaching out his hand, he touched him and said, “I am willing; be cleansed.”
1.42: In that moment his leprosy went from him and he was cleansed.
1.43: Yeshua reproved him and sent him out.
1.44: He said to him, “See that you tell no man, but go and show yourself to the priest. Bring gifts for your cleansing, just as Moses commanded for their testimony.”
1.45: But when he went out he began preaching it much and he reported the event so that Yeshua was not able to openly enter the cities. He was in deserted places and they were coming to him from every place.

2.1: Yeshua again entered Kapernahum for some days. When they heard that he was in the house,
2.2: So many were assembled that it was not able to hold them before the door. He was speaking the word with them
2.3: When a paralytic was brought to him, being carried by four men.
2.4: Because they were not able to be brought near him due to the crowds, they went up to the roof and removed the roof tiles of the place where Yeshua was. They let down the litter in which the paralytic lay.
2.5: When Yeshua saw their faith, he said to the paralytic, “My son, your sins are forgiven you.”
2.6: But some Scribes and Pharisees sitting there thought in their hearts,
2.7: “Who is this speaking blasphemy? Who is able to forgive sins except God alone?”
2.8: Yeshua knew in his Spirit that they were thinking these things in themselves. He said to them, “Why do you reason these things in your hearts?”
2.9: “What is easier to say to the paralytic: 'Your sins are forgiven you', or to say,'Arise, take your litter, and walk?”
2.10: “But that you may know The Son of Man is authorized to forgive sins in the earth”, he said to the paralytic:
2.11: “I say to you, get up, pick up your bed and go home.”
2.12: And immediately he stood up, picked up his pallet and went out before the eyes of all of them, so that they were all astonished and they glorified God, as they were saying, “We have never seen such a thing!”
2.13: And he went out again to the sea and all the crowds were coming to him and he was teaching them.
2.14: As he passed, he saw Levi, son of Khalphi, sitting down at the place of taxation and he said to him, “Come after me”, and rising he went after him.
2.15: And it was that as he reclined at supper in his house, there were many Tax Collectors and sinners reclining at supper with Yeshua and with his disciples, for many had come, and they were following him.
2.16: And when the Scribes and Pharisees saw him eating with Tax Collectors and with sinners, they said to his disciples, “How is it that he eats and drinks with Tax Collectors and sinners?”
2.17: But when Yeshua heard, he said to them, “The healthy have no need for a physician, but those who have become very ill; I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners.”
2.18: But the disciples of Yohannan and the Pharisees had been practicing fasting, and they came and they were saying to him, “Why do the disciples of Yohannan and of the Pharisees fast and your disciples do not fast?”
2.19: Yeshua said to them, “Are the children of the bridal chamber able to fast as long as the groom is with them? No!”
2.20: “But the days will come when the groom will be taken from them; then they will fast in those days.”
2.21: “No man places a new strip of cloth and sews it on an old garment lest the fullness of that new cloth takes from the old, and it rips more.”
2.22: “And no man pours new wine into old wineskins, lest the wine burst the wineskins and the wineskins are destroyed and the wine is spilled; but one pours new wine into new wineskins.”
2.23: And so it was that when Yeshua went out on the Sabbath to a grain field, his disciples were walking and picking the ears of wheat.
2.24: And the Pharisees were saying to him, “Look, why are they doing something that is illegal on the Sabbath?”
2.25: Yeshua said to them, “Have you never read what David did when he was in great need and was hungry, he and his companions,
2.26: As he entered the house of God when Abiathar was Chief Priest, and he ate the bread of the altar of THE LORD JEHOVAH, which was not legal to eat except for the priests? And he gave also to those who were with him.”
2.27: And he said to them, “The Sabbath was created for the sake of man and not man for the sake of the Sabbath.”
2.28: “Therefore The Son of Man is also master of the Sabbath.”

3.1: And Yeshua again entered the synagogue and a certain man was there, whose hand was shriveled.
3.2: And they were watching him, so that if he would heal him on the Sabbath, they might accuse him.
3.3: And he said to that man whose hand was shriveled, “Stand in the center.”
3.4: But he said also to them, “Is it legal to do what is good on the Sabbath or what is evil; to save life or to destroy?” But they were silent.
3.5: And he gazed at them in anger as he was grieved for the callousness of their hearts, and he said to that man, “Stretch out your hand.”, and he reached out and his hand was restored.
3.6: And the Pharisees went forth immediately with some of the house of Herodus and took counsel concerning him how they might destroy him.
3.7: And Yeshua with his disciples went to the sea, and many people from Galilee and from Judea had gone out.
3.8: And great crowds came to him from Jerusalem and from Edom and from the region of Jordan, and from Tyre and from Zidon, because they had heard everything that he had done.
3.9: And he told his disciples that they should bring him a ship because of the crowds, lest they would throng him.
3.10: For he was healing many until they would be falling on him so that they might touch him.
3.11: And those who had plagues from foul spirits, when they saw him, they were falling down and they were crying out and they were saying, “You are the Son of God!”
3.12: And he greatly rebuked them lest they would reveal him.
3.13: And he went up a mountain and he called those whom he wanted and they came to join him.
3.14: And he chose twelve to be with him, and to send them to preach
3.15: And to be authorized to heal the sick and to cast out devils.
3.16: And he gave Shimeon the name Kaypha,
3.17: And to Yaqob, the son of Zebedee and to Yohannan the brother of Yaqob he assigned the name B'nay Regshay, which is B'nay Rama
3.18: And Andreas and Philippus and Bar Tolmay and Mattay and Thoma and Yaqob son of Khalphi and Thadi and Shimeon the Zealot,
3.19: And Yehudah Skariota, he who would betray him, and they came to the house.
3.20: And crowds assembled again so that they were not going to be able to eat bread.
3.21: And his relatives heard and they went out to take hold of him, for they were saying, “He has gone out of his mind.”
3.22: And the Scribes who had come down from Jerusalem were saying, “He has Beelzebub in him and by The Ruler of devils he casts out devils.”
3.23: And Yeshua called them, and he said to them in parables, “How is Satan able to cast out Satan?”
3.24: “For if a kingdom will be divided against itself, that kingdom will not be able to stand.”
3.25: “And if a house will be divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand.”
3.26: “And if Satan were to rise up against himself and be divided, he would not be able to stand, but it would be his end.”
3.27: “A man cannot enter the house of a mighty one and rob his valuables, unless he first binds the mighty one, and then he shall plunder his house.”
3.28: “Truly I say to you, all sins and blasphemies that the sons of men will blaspheme shall be forgiven them,”
3.29: “But there is never forgiveness to whoever will blaspheme against The Spirit of Holiness, but he is condemned to eternal judgment;”
3.30: Because they were saying, “He has a foul spirit.”
3.31: And his mother and his brothers came, standing outside, and they sent that they might call him to them.
3.32: But the crowd was sitting around him, and they said to him, “Behold, your mother and your brothers are outside looking for you.”
3.33: And he answered and said to them, “Who is my mother and who are my brothers?”
3.34: And he looked on those who were sitting with him and he said, “Here is my mother and here are my brethren.”
3.35: “For whoever shall do the will of God is my brother and my sister and my mother.”

4.1: But he began teaching again at the seaside and great crowds were gathered to him, so that he would go up and sit in a boat in the sea and all the crowd was standing on land at the shore.
4.2: He was teaching them in many parables, and he said in his teaching:
4.3: “Listen; behold, a sower went out to sow.”
4.4: “And as he sowed, there was some that fell on the side of the road and a bird came and ate it.”
4.5: “But other seed fell on rock where there was not much soil, and immediately it sprouted because there was no depth of soil.”
4.6: “But when the sun arose it was scorched, and because it had no roots, it dried up.”
4.7: “Other fell among the thorns and the thorns came up and choked it, and it yielded no fruit.”
4.8: “But other fell in good ground, and it came up and grew and it yielded fruit, some thirtyfold and some sixtyfold and some an hundred fold.”
4.9: And he said, “Whoever has an ear to hear, let him hear.”
4.10: But when they were by themselves, those twelve who were with him inquired of him about that parable.
4.11: Yeshua said to them, “It has been given to you to know the secrets of the Kingdom of God, but to outsiders, everything has been in parables,”
4.12: “So that seeing they shall see and not see, and hearing they shall hear and they shall not understand, unless perhaps they shall be converted and their sins shall be forgiven them.”
4.13: He said to them, “Do you not know this parable? How shall you know all the parables?”
4.14: “The sower, who sowed, sowed the word.”
4.15: “But these upon the side of the road are those who have the word sown in them, and when they have heard, immediately Satan comes and takes the word away that was sown in their hearts.”
4.16: “And those that were sown upon the rock are those who when they have heard the word immediately receive it with joy.”
4.17: “And they have no root in themselves, but they abide for a while, and when there is distress or persecution because of the word, they are soon subverted.”
4.18: “And those sown among the thorns are those who have heard the word,”
4.19: “And the cares of this world and the seductiveness of wealth and other desires are entering in and choking the word and it becomes unfruitful.”
4.20: “And they that were sown in the good ground are those who hear the word and receive and yield fruit, thirtyfold, sixtyfold and an hundred fold.”
4.21: And he said to them, “Does one bring a lamp to be put under a basket or under a bed? Should it not be put on a lampstand?”
4.22: “For there is nothing covered that shall not be revealed, and nothing secret that will not be discovered.”
4.23: “If a man has an ear to hear, let him hear.”
4.24: And he said to them, “Take heed what you hear; that measure in which you are measuring is measured to you, and it is increased to you who hear.”
4.25: For whoever has it, it shall be given to him; and whoever does not have it, from him shall be taken even that which he has.
4.26: And he said, “Thus is the Kingdom of God like a man who cast seed in the ground.”
4.27: “And he shall sleep and arise by night and by day and the seed grows and lengthens while he is unaware.”
4.28: “For the earth produces fruit itself; first shall be the blade and afterward the ear, then finally the full wheat in the ear.”
4.29: “But whenever the fruit ripens, immediately the sickle is brought because the harvest has arrived.”
4.30: And he said, “to what shall we compare the Kingdom of God and with what parable shall we illustrate it?”
4.31: “It is like a grain of mustard seed, which when it is sown in the ground, is the smallest of all the herb seeds on the earth.”
4.32: “And when it is sown it comes up and becomes greater than all the small herbs and produces great branches, so that the birds will be able to perch in its shade.”
4.33: Yeshua was speaking parables like these with them, parables such as they were able to hear.
4.34: And without parables he was not speaking with them, but he expounded all things to his disciples privately.
4.35: He said to them that day in the evening, “Let us pass over to the other side.”
4.36: And they left the crowd and brought him as he was in the ship, and there were other boats with them.
4.37: And there was a great storm and the wind and the waves were beating into the ship and it was close to being filled.
4.38: But Yeshua was sleeping on a pillow in the stern of the ship and they came and awakened him and they were saying to him, “Our Master, do you not care that we are perishing?!”
4.39: And he arose and rebuked the wind and he said to the sea, “Stop! Shut up!”, and the wind stopped, and there was a great calm.
4.40: And he said to them, “Why are you so fearful? Why do you not have faith?”
4.41: And they were greatly afraid, and they were saying one to another, “Who is this, really, that the wind and sea obey him?”

5.1: And he came to the other side of the sea to the region of the Gadarenes.
5.2: And when he went out from the ship, a man met him from among the tombs that had a foul spirit in him.
5.3: And he dwelt among the tombs and no one was able to bind him with chains,
5.4: Because whenever he had been bound in shackles and chains he had broken the chains and cut the shackles apart and no one was able to subdue him.
5.5: And always at night and in the daytime he was among the tombs and in the mountains and was crying out and cutting himself with stones.
5.6: But when he saw Yeshua from a distance he ran and prostrated himself.
5.7: And he cried out in a loud voice and he said, “What do I have to do with you, Yeshua, Son of God Most High? I adjure you by God that you will not torture me!”
5.8: For he had said to him, “Come out from the man, foul spirit!”
5.9: And he had asked him, “What is your name?” He said to him, “Our name is Legion, for we are many.”
5.10: And he begged of him much that he would not send him out of the region.
5.11: But there was near the mountain a great herd of swine that were feeding.
5.12: And those evil spirits were begging of him and they were saying, “Send us unto those swine that we may enter them.”
5.13: And he allowed them, and these foul spirits went out and entered into the swine, and that herd ran to a precipice and fell into the sea, about 2000 of them, and they drowned in the water.
5.14: And they who were herding them fled and told it in the city, also in the villages, and they went out to see what had happened.
5.15: And they came to Yeshua and they saw him who had been possessed by the evil spirits with him, clothed and reverent, and he who before had the Legion in him was sitting, and they were afraid.
5.16: And those who had seen how it had been with him whom the evil spirits had possessed, reported to them, and also about those swine.
5.17: And they began to ask him to depart from their coast.
5.18: And after he embarked the ship, he whom the evil spirits had possessed was requesting of him that he might remain with him.
5.19: And he did not allow him, but he said to him, “Go to your house to your people and relate to them what THE LORD JEHOVAH has done for you and that he has had compassion upon you.”
5.20: And he departed and he began preaching in the ten cities what Yeshua had done for him, and they were all astounded.
5.21: And after Yeshua had crossed in the ship to the other side, great crowds were again assembled unto him while he was on the seaside.
5.22: And one of The Rulers of the synagogue, whose name was Yorash, came, and when he had seen him, he fell at his feet.
5.23: And he was begging him greatly and he said to him, “My daughter has become very ill; come lay your hand upon her and she will be healed, and she will live.”
5.24: And Yeshua went on with him and a great crowd was close to him and pressing upon him.
5.25: But there was a certain woman who had a flow of blood twelve years
5.26: Who had suffered greatly from many physicians and had spent everything that she had and she had not been helped at all, but she had become even worse.
5.27: When she heard about Yeshua, she came in the press of the crowd from behind him and she touched his garment,
5.28: For she said, “ If I touch even his garment, I shall be saved.”
5.29: And at once the fount of her blood dried up, and she sensed in her body that she was healed of her plague.
5.30: But Yeshua knew in himself at once that power had gone out from him and he turned to the crowds and he said, “Who has touched my garment?”
5.31: And his disciples were saying to him, “You see the crowd pressing against you, and do you say, 'Who has touched me?' “
5.32: And he was gazing that he might see who had done this.
5.33: But that woman, being afraid and trembling, for she knew what had happened to her, came and fell down before him and told him all the truth.
5.34: But he said to her, “My daughter, your faith has saved you; go in peace and be whole from your disease.”
5.35: And while he was speaking, those who were from the house of The Ruler of the synagogue came, and they were saying, “Your daughter has died. Why should you now trouble The Teacher?”
5.36: But Yeshua heard the words which they spoke and he said to The Ruler of the assembly, “Do not fear; only believe.”
5.37: And he allowed no one to go with him except Shimeon Kaypha and Yaqob and Yohannan, brother of Yaqob.
5.38: And they came to The Chief of the assembly's house and he saw those who were disturbed and weeping and wailing.
5.39: And he entered and he said to them, “Why are you disturbed and weeping? The girl is not dead, but she is sleeping.”
5.40: And they were laughing at him, but he put all of them out and he took the father of the girl and her mother, and those who were with him, and he entered the place where the girl was lying.
5.41: And he took the girl's hand and he said to her, “Little girl, arise.”
5.42: Immediately the young girl arose, and she was walking, for she was twelve years old, and they were astounded with great astonishment.
5.43: And he commanded them strictly that they should not relate this to anyone, and he said that they should give her food.

6.1: And he went out from there and he came to the city, and his disciples were staying close to him.
6.2: And when it was The Sabbath, he began to teach in the synagogue and many who heard were amazed and they were saying, “From where does this man have these things? What is this wisdom given to him that mighty works like these should be done by his hands?”
6.3: “Is this not the carpenter, son of Maryam and brother of Yaqob, and Yose and Yehudah and Shimeon, and are not his sisters here with us?” And they were suspicious of him.
6.4: And Yeshua said to them, “There is no Prophet who is despised except in his city and among his kindred and in his house.”
6.5: And he was not able to do even one powerful work there, but only laid his hands upon a few sick folks and healed them.
6.6: He was astonished at the lack of their faith and he was going around in the villages as he taught.
6.7: And he called his twelve and he began to send them two by two and he gave them authority over vile spirits to cast them out.
6.8: And he commanded them that they would not take anything on the road except perhaps a staff, no bag, no bread, no copper in their purses,
6.9: But that they would wear sandals, and they should not wear two tunics.
6.10: And he said to them, “Into whatever house you enter, stay there until you depart from there.”
6.11: “And all who will not receive you and will not hear you, when you leave that place, shake off the dust that is on the soles of your feet for their testimony; truly I say to you that it will be tranquil for Sadom and Amorah in the day of judgment compared to that city.”
6.12: And they went out and they preached that they should return to God.
6.13: And they were casting out many evil spirits, and they were anointing the many sick with oil and they were healing them.
6.14: And Herodus The King heard about Yeshua, for his name was known to him and he said, “He is Yohannan The Baptizer; he is raised from the grave, therefore, mighty works are performed by him.”
6.15: Others were saying, “He is Elijah”, and others, “He is a Prophet like one of The Prophets.”
6.16: Now when Herodus heard, he said, “Yohannan, whose head I cut off, has arisen from the grave.”
6.17: For Herodus had sent and seized Yohannan and bound him in the prison for the sake of Herodia whom he had taken, the wife of Phillipus his brother.
6.18: For Yohannan had said to Herodus, “It is not lawful for you to take the wife of your brother.”
6.19: But Herodia was threatening him and she wanted to kill him and was unable.
6.20: Herodus had been afraid of Yohannan because he had known that he was a righteous and holy man, and he protected him and he heard many things that he had said and did services for him, and he heard him with pleasure.
6.21: It was a notable day when Herodus made a supper for his nobles and for the Captains and the Leaders of Galilee on his birthday.
