6.22: And the daughter of Herodia came in, and she danced, and she pleased Herodus and those who were reclining with him, and The King said to the girl, “Ask of me anything that you desire, and I shall give it to you.”
6.23: And he swore to her, “Anything that you shall ask, I shall give to you, unto the half of my Kingdom.”
6.24: But she went out and said to her mother, “What shall I ask?” She said to her, “The head of Yohannan The Baptizer.”
6.25: At once she entered with diligence to the King, and she said to him, “I want you to give me on a dish, this hour, the head of Yohannan The Baptizer.”
6.26: And it grieved The King much, but because of the oath and because of the dinner guests, he was unwilling to deny her.
6.27: The King sent the executioner at once and commanded to bring the head of Yohannan and he went and cut off the head of Yohannan in the prison.
6.28: And he brought it on a plate and he gave it to the girl and the girl gave it to her mother.
6.29: His disciples heard and they came and took his corpse and laid it in a tomb.
6.30: And The Apostles were gathered unto Yeshua and they told him everything that they had done and everything whatever they had taught.
6.31: And he said to them, “Come, we shall go to the country alone and rest yourselves a little.” For there were many going and coming and there was not a place for them even to eat.
6.32: And they went to a deserted place in a ship by themselves.
6.33: And many saw them as they were going, and they recognized them and they ran on land from all the cities before him to that place.
6.34: And Yeshua went forth, seeing the great crowds, and he was moved with pity on them, for they were like sheep without a shepherd, and he began to teach them many things.
6.35: And when the time had grown late, his disciples came to him and they were saying to him, “This is a desolate place and the time is late.”
6.36: “Dismiss them that they may go to the market that they may go around to the villages also and buy bread for themselves, for there is nothing for them to eat.”
6.37: He said to them, “You give them food.” They said to him, “Shall we go buy 200 denarii of bread and give them to eat?”
6.38: He said to them, “Go see how many loaves you have here.” When they looked, they said to him, “Five loaves and two fish.”
6.39: And he commanded them to seat everyone on the grass.
6.40: And they were seated by hundreds and by 50's.
6.41: And he took those five loaves and two fish and gazed into Heaven and he blessed and broke the bread, and he gave to his disciples to set before them and they divided those two fish for all of them.
6.42: And they all ate and they were filled.
6.43: And they took up twelve baskets full of the fragments and also of the fish.
6.44: Now those who ate the bread were 5000 men.
6.45: And at once he urged his disciples to board the ship and go before him to the other side to Bethsaida while he sent the multitude away.
6.46: And when he had sent them away he went to a mountain to pray.
6.47: But when it had become evening, the boat was in the middle of the sea and he was alone on the land.
6.48: And he saw them laboring as they were rowing, for the wind was against them. And it was, that in the fourth watch of the night, Yeshua came toward them as he was walking on the sea, and he wanted to pass by them.
6.49: They saw him that he was walking on the water, and they thought to themselves that he was a hallucination and they cried out,
6.50: For they all saw him and they were afraid and immediately he spoke with them and he said to them, “Take heart, I AM THE LIVING GOD; do not be afraid.”
6.51: And he came up to join them in the ship and the wind ceased, and they were greatly astonished and they wondered in their souls.
6.52: For they had not learned from the bread, because their heart was stupid.
6.53: And when they had crossed to the other side, they came to the land of Genesar.
6.54: And when they went out from the boat, immediately the men of the place recognized him.
6.55: And they ran in all that area, and they began to bring those who had become sick, as they were carrying them in litters to the place where they heard that he was.
6.56: And wherever he had entered a village or city, they were laying the sick in the streets, and they were begging him if they might touch even the fringe of his garment, and all those who were touching it were healed.

7.1: The Pharisees and the Scribes who had come from Jerusalem gathered around him.
7.2: And they saw some of his disciples eating bread when they had not washed their hands, and they found fault.
7.3: For all the Judeans and the Pharisees do not eat unless they wash their hands carefully because they keep the tradition of the Elders.
7.4: And coming from the marketplace, unless they bathe, they do not eat. And there are many other things which they had received to keep: washings of cups and pots and copper vessels and of beds.
7.5: And the Scribes and Pharisees asked him, “Why do your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the Elders, but eat bread without having washed their hands?”
7.6: But he said to them, “Isaiah the Prophet prophesied beautifully of you impostors, just as it is written: 'This people honors me with its lips, but their heart is very far from Me.'
7.7: 'And in vain they pay reverence to me as they teach doctrines of commandments of the sons of men.'
7.8: “You forsake the commandments of God and you keep the traditions of the sons of men: washings of cups and pots and many such things like these.”
7.9: He said to them, “Well you reject the commandment of God that you may establish your traditions.”
7.10: For Moses said, “Honor your father and your mother”, and “Whoever reviles father and mother shall die the death.”
7.11: But you say, “If a man shall say to his father or to his mother, 'My offering is anything that you shall gain from me.'
7.12: Then you do not allow him to do anything for his father or his mother.
7.13: And you reject the word of God for the traditions that you deliver, and many things like these you do.”
7.14: And Yeshua called to all the crowds, and he said to them, “Hear me all of you and understand.”
7.15: “There is nothing outside of a man that enters into him that can defile him, but the thing that proceeds from him, that is what defiles the man.”
7.16: “Whoever has an ear to hear, let him hear.”
7.17: But when Yeshua entered the house from the crowds, his disciples asked him about that parable.
7.18: He said to them, “Are you also stupid? Do you not know that nothing entering from outside a man can defile him?”
7.19: “Because it does not enter his heart, but his belly, and is discharged by excretion, which purifies all foods.”
7.20: “But the thing that proceeds from a man, that defiles the man.”
7.21: “For from within the heart of the children of men proceed evil ideas, adultery, fornication, theft, murder.”
7.22: “Greed, wickedness, deceit, harlotry, an evil eye, blasphemy, boasting, senselessness.”
7.23: “All these evils proceed from within and defile a man.”
7.24: Yeshua arose from there and came to the coast of Tyre and of Sidon, and he entered a certain house and he did not want anyone to know him and he could not be hidden.
7.25: For immediately a certain woman heard about him, whose daughter had a foul spirit, and she came falling before his feet.
7.26: But she was a pagan woman from Phoenicia of Syria, and she was begging him to cast out the demon from her daughter.
7.27: And Yeshua said to her, “Let the children be filled first, for it is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the dogs.”
7.28: But she answered and said to him, “Yes, my lord, but even the dogs from under the table eat the children's crumbs.”
7.29: Yeshua said to her, “Go; because of this saying the demon has gone out from your daughter.”
7.30: And she went to her house and found her daughter lying in bed, and the demon had been cast out of her.
7.31: Yeshua again went out from the coast of Tyre and Sidon, and he came to the Sea of Galilee at the border of The Ten Cities.
7.32: And they brought him a certain deaf man who was dumb and they begged him to lay hands upon him.
7.33: And he took him aside from the crowd alone and put his fingers in his ears and spat and he touched his tongue.
7.34: And he gazed into Heaven and he groaned and he said to him, “Be opened.”
7.35: And at that moment his ears were opened and a bond of his tongue was released and he spoke distinctly.
7.36: And he warned them not to tell anyone, and as much as he warned them, they all the more proclaimed it.
7.37: And they were greatly astonished, and they were saying, “He has done everything beautifully; he has made the deaf to hear and him who was mute to speak.”

8.1: But in those days when there was a great crowd and there was nothing for them to eat, he called his disciples and said to them:
8.2: “I have pity on this crowd, for behold, they have continued with me three days and there is nothing for them to eat.”
8.3: “And if I send them away fasting to their houses they will faint in the road, for some among them have come from far away.”
8.4: His disciples said to him, “From where here in the desert can a man supply enough bread for all of these?”
8.5: He asked them, “How many loaves do you have?, and they said, “Seven.”
8.6: And he commanded the crowds to recline on the ground and he took those seven loaves and blessed and broke and he gave to his disciples to be set out, and they set them out for the crowd.
8.7: And there were a few fish also for them, and he blessed them, and he said to set them out.
8.8: And they ate and were filled and they took up the leftovers of fragments seven baskets.
8.9: But there were about 4000 men who ate.
8.10: And he sent them away and came up at once to the ship with his disciples and came to the region of Dalmanutha.
8.11: And Pharisees came out and they began to inquire with him and they were asking him for a sign from Heaven, while tempting him.
8.12: And he groaned in his spirit and he said, “Why does this generation seek for a sign? Truly I say to you, a sign shall not be given to this generation.”
8.13: And he left them and boarded the ship and they went to the other side.
8.14: They had forgotten to take bread, and except for one cake, there was nothing with them in the ship.
8.15: And he commanded them and he said to them, “Behold, beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the leaven of Herodus.”
8.16: And they were reasoning with one another, and they were saying, “It is because we have no bread.”
8.17: But Yeshua knew and he said to them, “Why are you considering that you have no bread? Do you not yet know? Do you not yet understand? Your heart is still hard.”
8.18: “You have eyes and do not see and you have ears and you do not hear, neither do you remember.”
8.19: “When I broke those five loaves for the 5000, after they were filled, how many baskets of fragments did you take up?” They said to him, “Twelve.”
8.20: He said to them, “And when the seven to the 4000, after they were filled, how many baskets of fragments did you take up?” They said, “Seven.”
8.21: He said to them, “How is it that you still do not understand?”
8.22: And he came to Bethsaida, and they brought a blind man to him, and they were begging him to touch him.
8.23: And he grasped the hand of the blind man and took him outside the town and he spat in his eyes and laid his hand upon him and he asked him what he saw.
8.24: He gazed and he said, “I see people like trees that are walking.”
8.25: He laid his hand again on his eyes and he was healed, and he saw everything clearly.
8.26: And he sent him to his house and he said, “Do not enter the town, neither tell anyone in the town.”
8.27: Yeshua and his disciples went out to the villages of Caesarea Philippi, and he was asking his disciples in the road and he said to them, “What is it the people are saying about me as to who I am?”
8.28: Some said, “Yohannan the Baptizer”, and others “Elijah” and others, “One of The Prophets.”
8.29: And Yeshua said to them, “But what is it you are saying about me as to who I am?” Shimeon answered and he said to him, “You are The Messiah, The Son of THE LIVING GOD.”
8.30: And he admonished them that they should not speak about him to anyone.
8.31: And he began to teach them: “The Son of Man is going to suffer many things and to be rejected by the Elders and by the Chief Priests and by the Scribes and he shall be killed, and in three days he shall rise.”
8.32: And he was speaking the word openly and Kaypha took him aside and began to rebuke him.
8.33: But he turned and gazed at his disciples and rebuked Shimeon and said, “Depart behind me Satan, for you do not reason of God, but of the children of men.”
8.34: And Yeshua called the crowds with his disciples, and he said to them, “Whoever is willing to come after me, let him renounce himself and take up his cross and let him come after me.”
8.35: “Whoever desires to save his soul will lose it. Everyone who will lose his life for me and for my gospel will save it.”
8.36: “For how is a man benefited if he should gain the whole world and he should lose his soul?”
8.37: “Or what payment shall a man give to regain his soul again?
8.38: “For everyone who shall be ashamed of me and my words in this sinning and adultery committing generation, of him also shall The Son of Man be ashamed whenever he comes in the glory of his Father with his Holy Angels.”

9.1: And he said to them, “Amen, I say to you, there are men standing here who shall not taste death until they will behold the Kingdom of God coming with wonders.”
9.2: And after six days Yeshua led Kaypha, Yaqob and Yohannan and took them up to a high mountain by themselves and he was transfigured before their eyes.
9.3: And his garment was shining and became very white, like snow, in a manner by which men on earth are not able to whiten.
9.4: And Elijah and Moses appeared to them as they were speaking with Yeshua.
9.5: And Kaypha said to him, “Rabbi, it is beautiful for us to be here; let us make three tabernacles, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
9.6: But he did not know what he was saying, for they were in awe.
9.7: And there was a cloud and it was a shelter about them, and a voice from the cloud which said, “This is my Beloved Son, hear him.”
9.8: And suddenly afterward, the disciples gazed up, and they saw no one except Yeshua alone with them.
9.9: And when they descended from the mountain, he commanded them that they would tell no one anything that they had seen until after The Son of Man had risen from the dead.
9.10: And they seized on that statement in their souls and they were inquiring, “What is this statement, 'When he rises from among the dead?”
9.11: And they asked him and they said, “Why do the Scribes say therefore that Elijah must come first?”
9.12: He said to them, “Elijah does come first, so that he may prepare all things, and just as it is written about The Son of Man, he will suffer much and be rejected.”
9.13: “But I say to you also that Elijah has come and they did to him everything whatever they wished, just as it is written about him.”
9.14: And when he came to the disciples he saw the great crowds among them and the Scribes debating with them.
9.15: And immediately all the crowds saw him and they were astonished and ran and greeted him.
9.16: And he was asking The Scribes, “What are you debating with them?”
9.17: And one from the crowds answered and said, “Teacher, I brought my son to you, who has a dumb spirit.”
9.18: “And whenever it comes upon him, it throws him and it beats him and he gnashes his teeth and he wastes away, and I spoke to your disciples that they might cast it out, and they were not able.”
9.19: Yeshua answered and said to them, “Oh faithless generation, how long will I be with you? How long shall I endure you? Bring him to me.”
9.20: And they brought him to him, and when the spirit saw him, immediately he threw him and he fell on the ground and he was convulsed and he foamed.
9.21: Yeshua asked his father, “How long a time now has he been like this? He said to him, “From his childhood.”
9.22: “And many times it has thrown him into fire and into water to destroy him. But if you can do anything, help me, and have mercy on me!”
9.23: Yeshua said to him, “If you are able to believe, everything is possible to the one who believes.”
9.24: And immediately the father of the boy cried out weeping and saying, “I believe my lord; help the lack of my faith.”
9.25: And when Yeshua saw that the people ran and gathered near him, he rebuked that foul spirit and he said to it, “Deaf spirit, that does not speak, I am commanding you, go out from him, and you shall not enter him again.”
9.26: And that demon screamed greatly and pounded him and went out and he was like a dead man, so that many were saying, “He is dead.”
9.27: But Yeshua took him by his hand and raised him up.
9.28: But when Yeshua had entered the house, his disciples asked him among themselves, “Why were we not able to cast it out?”
9.29: He said to them, “This sort cannot come out by anything except by fasting and by prayer.”
9.30: And when he went out from there, they were passing through Galilee, and he did not want anyone to recognize him.
9.31: For he was teaching his disciples and he said to them, “The Son of Man will be delivered into the hands of men and they will kill him, and when he has been killed, on the third day he shall rise.”
9.32: But they did not understand that saying, and they were afraid to ask him.
9.33: And they came to Kapernahum and when they entered the house, he asked them, “What were you reasoning on the road among yourselves?”
9.34: But they were silent, for they had been arguing on the road with one another who was the greatest among them.
9.35: And Yeshua sat down and he called the twelve and he said to them, “He who wants to be first shall be last, and the servant of every person.”
9.36: And he took a certain boy and stood him in the midst and took him up on his shoulders and he said to them:
9.37: “Whoever shall receive one boy like this in my name is receiving me, and whoever receives me has not received me, but him who sent me.
9.38: Yohannan said to him, “Rabbi, we saw a man casting out demons in your name, and we forbade him because he did not go out with us.”
9.39: Yeshua said to them, “Do not forbid him, for there is no man who does a powerful work in my name and can soon speak badly about me.”
9.40: “Whoever therefore is not against you is for you.”
9.41: “But everyone who will give you only a cup of water to drink in the name that you are one who belongs to The Messiah, amen, I say to you, he shall not lose his reward.”
9.42: “And everyone who shall subvert one of these little ones who believe in me, it were better for him if a millstone of a donkey were hung around his neck and he were cast into the sea.”
9.43: “If your hand causes subverts you, cut it off, for it is better for you that you enter the Life maimed, than when you have two hands, you would go to Gehenna.”
9.44: “Where their worm does not die and their fire is not quenched.”
9.45: “If your foot subverts you, cut it off, for it is better for you to enter the Life crippled than when you have two feet that you should fall into Gehenna.”
9.46: “Where their worm does not die and their fire is not quenched.”
9.47: “And if your eye subverts you, pluck it out, for is better for you that you should enter the Kingdom of God with one eye than having two eyes that you should fall into the Gehenna of fire.”
9.48: “Where their worm does not die and their fire is not quenched.”
9.49: “For everything will be seasoned with fire and every sacrifice will be seasoned with salt.”
9.50: “Salt is excellent, but if salt becomes tasteless, with what shall it be seasoned? Have salt in you and be at peace with one another.”

10.1: And he arose from there and came to the borders of Judea to the crossing of the Jordan, and great crowds went there to join him, and he taught them again as he had been accustomed.
10.2: And Pharisees approached, tempting him, and asking, “Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?”
10.3: He said to them, “What has Moses commanded you?”
10.4: But they said, “Moses allowed us to write a letter of divorce and we may get a divorce.”
10.5: Yeshua answered and he said to them, “He wrote you this commandment confronting the callousness of your heart.”
10.6: “But from the beginning, God made them male and female.”
10.7: “Because of this a man shall leave his father and mother and cleave to his wife.”
10.8: “And the two shall be one flesh; after that they are not two, but one flesh.”
10.9: “The things that God unites let not a son of man separate.”
10.10: And his disciples asked him again in the house about this.
10.11: And he said to them, “Every man who divorces his wife and takes another commits adultery.”
10.12: “And if a woman divorces her husband and another man shall have her, she commits adultery.”
10.13: And they were bringing children to him that he might touch them, but his disciples were rebuking those who brought them.
10.14: But Yeshua saw and was displeased and he said to them, “Let the children come to me and do not forbid them, for the Kingdom of God belongs to such as these.”
10.15: “Amen, I say to you, no one who will not receive the Kingdom of God like a child will enter it.”
10.16: And he took them up in his arms and he laid his hand upon them and he blessed them.
10.17: And as he traveled on the road, one came running and fell on his knees and asked him and said, “Good teacher, what shall I do that I may inherit eternal life?”
10.18: Yeshua said to him, “Why do you call me good? There is no one good but The One God.”
10.19: “You know the commandments: 'You shall not commit adultery', 'You shall not steal', 'You shall not murder', 'You shall not give false testimony', 'You shall not cheat', 'Honor your father and your mother.' “
10.20: He answered and said to him, “Teacher, I have kept all these things from my childhood.”
10.21: But Yeshua gazed at him and he loved him and he said to him: “You have one thing missing: go sell everything that you have and give to the poor, and you shall have treasure in Heaven, and take the cross and come after me.”
10.22: But he was saddened at this saying and he departed grieving, because he had great wealth.
10.23: But Yeshua gazed at his disciples and he said to them, “How hard it is for those who have wealth to enter the Kingdom of God!”
10.24: But the disciples were astonished at his words. And Yeshua answered again and he said to them, “Children, how hard it is for those who rely upon their wealth to enter the Kingdom of God!”
10.25: “It is easier for a camel to enter into the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God.”
10.26: But they were all the more astonished, and they were saying among themselves, “Who can be saved?”
10.27: But Yeshua gazed upon them and he said to them, “With the sons of men, this is impossible, but not with God; everything is possible with God.”
10.28: Kaypha began to say, “Behold, we have left everything and have cleaved to you.”
10.29: Yeshua answered and said, “Amen, I say to you, there is no man who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or town for my sake and for my Gospel's sake,
10.30: Who will not receive each one an hundredfold now in this time, houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and towns, with persecutions, and in the world that is coming, eternal life.
10.31: But many are first who shall be last, and the last first.”
